name: AjaxRequest
definition: AjaxRequest events occur for any Ajax request, including during a BrowserInteraction event. The event attribute tracks geographic and browser info. Use browser app settings to block specific requests.

attributes.definition: The text of the HTML element that was clicked when a browser interaction started. Added to BrowserInteraction and any AjaxRequest, JavaScriptError and BrowserTiming events that occurred during that interaction.
attributes.name: actionText

attributes.definition: The ID of your application, as recorded by New Relic.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the application that handled the request as shown in browser monitoring.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asnLongitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asnOrganization

attributes.definition: A unique value generated for each browser interaction captured by the New Relic agent.
attributes.name: browserInteractionId

attributes.definition: The name of the interaction. This is either the targetGroupedUrl or the custom name set via the API.
attributes.name: browserInteractionName

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: countryCode

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: mobile, tablet, or desktop.
attributes.name: deviceType

attributes.definition: A value that you can link to multiple BrowserInteraction events so you can view the interactions that occurred surrounding a specific event. For example, you can see the browser interactions that occurred prior to a JavaScript error.
attributes.name: eventId

attributes.definition: The grouped URL of the view that made the AJAX request. For example: myapp.com/acct/\*/dash.
attributes.name: groupedPageURL

attributes.definition: The grouped URL of the AJAX request. For example: myapp.com/acct/\*/ajax.
attributes.name: groupedRequestUrl

attributes.definition: The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the request URL.
attributes.name: hostname

attributes.definition: The HTTP method of the AJAX request. Example: POST.
attributes.name: httpMethod

attributes.definition: The HTTP response code. Example: 200.
attributes.name: httpResponseCode

attributes.definition: The total duration, in seconds, spent on JavaScript execution. This attribute is only seen in AjaxRequest data that is tied to BrowserInteraction. This attribute doesn't exist for initial page load events.
attributes.name: jsDuration

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that was loaded for the PageView, for example: http://www.newrelic.com. This URL does not include query parameters.
attributes.name: pageUrl

attributes.definition: A unique value generated for each interaction with the page. You can use this value to group interactions together.
attributes.name: parentEventId

attributes.definition: The request port.
attributes.name: port

attributes.definition: Likelihood this event will be saved.
attributes.name: priority

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the PageView event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes.

In the United States, regions correspond to state codes ; for example, WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes .
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: The payload size of the request body, in bytes.
attributes.name: requestBodySize

attributes.definition: The URL of the AJAX request. For example: myapp.com/acct/1/ajax.
attributes.name: requestUrl

attributes.definition: The payload size of the response body, in bytes.
attributes.name: responseBodySize

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single session. The session cookie expires when the user closes the browser (for example, they fully exit Chrome.) A new session identifier will be assigned when the user opens up a new instance of the browser.
attributes.name: session

attributes.definition: Allows for linking together end user actions from session traces and querying across browser events. Not all browser events will have this. For example, PageView events complete before the first session trace harvest. Also, initial page loads from BrowserInteraction won't always include this.
attributes.name: sessionTraceId

attributes.definition: The time in seconds between the start of the BrowserInteraction and the start of the request.
attributes.name: timeSinceBrowserInteractionStart

attributes.definition: The duration, in seconds, from the start of the request (timestamp) to the end of the last callback. This is not just an additive function; the callback time can overlap with the wait time. This attribute is only seen in AjaxRequest data that is tied to BrowserInteraction.
attributes.name: timeToLastCallbackEnd

attributes.definition:
The time, in seconds, from the start of the AJAX request to the start of its load event. This value represents the duration of the AJAX request with single page app (SPA) monitoring.

For more information, see the Mozilla developer documentation about XMLHttpRequest load events.
attributes.name: timeToLoadEventStart

attributes.definition: The time, in seconds, from the start of the request to when all resulting callbacks (including callbacks of subsequent AJAX requests) are complete. This attribute is only seen in AjaxRequest data that is tied to BrowserInteraction.
attributes.name: timeToSettle

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The browser’s name, such as Chrome and Firefox, obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentName

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported operating system, such as Windows or Linux, that it is running on. This is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentOS

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported software version, which is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentVersion

name: AwsLambdaInvocation
definition: This event is reported by New Relic monitoring for AWS Lambda. This event captures overall function timing and associated metadata. A single AwsLambdaInvocation event is generated for each invocation.

attributes.definition: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instrumented Lambda function.
attributes.name: aws.lambda.arn

attributes.definition: A boolean indicating if the AWS Lambda invocation is a cold start.
attributes.name: aws.lambda.coldStart

attributes.definition: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the entity that invoked the instrumented Lambda function.
attributes.name: aws.lambda.eventSource.arn

attributes.definition: AWS identifier of the invocation.
attributes.name: aws.requestId

attributes.definition: The number of database calls made by this transaction.
attributes.name: databaseCallCount

attributes.definition: The database response time in seconds.
attributes.name: databaseDuration

attributes.definition: The total invocation time for the transaction, in seconds. (Data source: AWS Lambda)
attributes.name: duration

attributes.definition: The number of external calls made by this transaction.
attributes.name: externalCallCount

attributes.definition: The total response time of all external (out-of-process) services, in seconds.
attributes.name: externalDuration

attributes.definition: Where the data point entered the platform (such as browser.spans, or api.traces).
attributes.name: newRelic.ingestPoint

attributes.definition: If a distributed tracing payload is received, this is the account identifier for the transaction's upstream caller.
attributes.name: parent.account

attributes.definition: If a distributed tracing payload is received, this is the application identifier. APM agents retrieve this value in the connect response under the key primary_application_id.
attributes.name: parent.app

attributes.definition: When a distributed tracing payload is received, the method of transport for the payload. Example values: Unknown, HTTP, HTTPS, Kafka, JMS, IronMQ, AMQP, Queue, or Other.
attributes.name: parent.transportType

attributes.definition: If a distributed trace payload was received, the parent's data source type. Example values: App, Browser, Mobile.
attributes.name: parent.type

attributes.definition: The types as read from the HTTP Accept request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.accept

attributes.definition: Incoming request size in bytes as read from the Content-Length HTTP request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.contentLength

attributes.definition: Incoming request content-type as read from the HTTP request header Content-Type. Example value: application/octet-stream.
attributes.name: request.headers.contentType

attributes.definition: The name from the HTTP host request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.host

attributes.definition: The incoming request referer as read from the Referer request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.referer

attributes.definition: The contents of the User-Agent HTTP header.
attributes.name: request.headers.userAgent

attributes.definition: The HTTP request method used. Example values: POST, GET.
attributes.name: request.method

attributes.definition: The outgoing response size in bytes as read from the Content-Length response header.
attributes.name: response.headers.contentLength

attributes.definition: For an HTTP response, the data type of the returned response. Example values: text/html, application/json.
attributes.name: response.headers.contentType

attributes.definition: The response code for an HTTP request
attributes.name: response.status

attributes.definition: The sum of all async components' duration, in seconds. An async component is a method or function where there is no instrumented encapsulating method or function.
attributes.name: totalTime

attributes.definition: The unique ID (a randomly generated string) used to identify a single request as it crosses inter- and intra- process boundaries. This ID allows the linking of spans in a distributed trace. Included when distributed tracing is enabled.
attributes.name: traceId

attributes.definition: The New Relic event type. Example values: Transaction, Span.
attributes.name: type

name: AwsLambdaInvocationError

attributes.definition: A boolean indicating if the AWS Lambda invocation is a cold start.

attributes.definition: The number of database calls made by this transaction.

attributes.definition: Where the data point entered the platform (such as browser.spans, or api.traces).

attributes.definition: If a distributed tracing payload is received, this is the account identifier for the transaction's upstream caller.

attributes.definition: If a distributed tracing payload is received, this is the application identifier. APM agents retrieve this value in the connect response under the key primary_application_id.

attributes.definition: When a distributed tracing payload is received, the method of transport for the payload. Example values: Unknown, HTTP, HTTPS, Kafka, JMS, IronMQ, AMQP, Queue, or Other.
attributes.name: parent.transportType

attributes.definition: If a distributed trace payload was received, the parent's data source type. Example values: App, Browser, Mobile.
attributes.name: parent.type

attributes.definition: The types as read from the HTTP Accept request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.accept

attributes.definition: Incoming request size in bytes as read from the Content-Length HTTP request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.contentLength

attributes.definition: Incoming request content-type as read from the HTTP request header Content-Type. Example value: application/octet-stream.
attributes.name: request.headers.contentType

attributes.definition: The name from the HTTP host request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.host

attributes.definition: The incoming request referer as read from the Referer request header.
attributes.name: request.headers.referer

attributes.definition: The contents of the User-Agent HTTP header.
attributes.name: request.headers.userAgent

attributes.definition: The HTTP request method used. Example values: POST, GET.
attributes.name: request.method

attributes.definition: The outgoing response size in bytes as read from the Content-Length response header.
attributes.name: response.headers.contentLength

attributes.definition: For an HTTP response, the data type of the returned response. Example values: text/html, application/json.
attributes.name: response.headers.contentType

attributes.definition: The error stack trace. The format will be different depending on the agent language.
attributes.name: stackTrace

attributes.definition: The unique ID (a randomly generated string) used to identify a single request as it crosses inter- and intra- process boundaries. This ID allows the linking of spans in a distributed trace. Included when distributed tracing is enabled.
attributes.name: traceId

attributes.definition: Name of the transaction in which the error occurred. Example value: Controller/customers/show. Value may be 'Unknown' if an error occurs outside of a transaction.
attributes.name: transactionName

attributes.definition: The New Relic event type. Example values: Transaction, Span.
attributes.name: type

name: BrowserInteraction
definition: A BrowserInteraction represents a unit of work in a browser session, triggered by a user interacting with the webpage. It captures information about the session, AJAX calls and custom JavaScript timing that occurred as a result of the interaction. Initial load and route changes are captured as special types of browser interactions, and are used for SPA monitoring.

attributes.definition: The text of the HTML element that was clicked when a browser interaction started. Added to BrowserInteraction and any AjaxRequest, JavaScriptError and BrowserTiming events that occurred during that interaction.
attributes.name: actionText

attributes.definition: A count of all XHRs included in the timing of a SPA interaction.
attributes.name: ajaxCount

attributes.definition: The ID of your application, as recorded by New Relic.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the application that handled the request as shown in browser monitoring.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asnLongitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asnOrganization

attributes.definition: The name of the backend transaction that served the initial page load.
attributes.name: backendTransactionName

attributes.definition: The type of interaction; either initial page load, route change, or custom.

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: mobile, tablet, or desktop.

attributes.definition: The domain portion of the request URL.
attributes.name: domain

attributes.definition: The total time elapsed of the interaction event
attributes.name: duration

attributes.definition: A value that you can link to multiple BrowserInteraction events so you can view the interactions that occurred surrounding a specific event. For example, you can see the browser interactions that occurred prior to a JavaScript error.
attributes.name: eventId

attributes.definition:
firstContentfulPaint is the point when the browser renders the first bit of content from the DOM, which may be text, an image, SVG, or a <canvas> element.

Google's User-centric Performance Metrics contains detailed information about its Paint Timing API and firstContentfulPaint.

See Compatibility and requirements for New Relic Browser for additional information about firstContentfulPaint browser compatibility.
attributes.name: firstContentfulPaint

attributes.definition:
firstPaint marks the point when the browser renders anything that is visually different from what was on the screen prior to navigation. This includes non-default background paint and the enclosing box of an iframe.

Google's User-centric Performance Metrics contains detailed information about its Paint Timing API and firstPaint.

See Compatibility and requirements for New Relic Browser for additional information about firstPaint browser compatibility.
attributes.name: firstPaint

attributes.definition: The total duration, in seconds, spent on JavaScript execution. This attribute is only seen in AjaxRequest data that is tied to BrowserInteraction. This attribute doesn't exist for initial page load events.
attributes.name: jsDuration

attributes.definition: The synthetic monitoring account from which you are running the monitor.
attributes.name: monitorAccountId

attributes.definition: A unique number identifying a particular monitor.
attributes.name: monitorId

attributes.definition: The ID of a single synthetic monitor run, which began at a specific time and originated from a specific location.
attributes.name: monitorJobId

attributes.definition: A unique value generated for each interaction with the page. You can use this value to group interactions together.
attributes.name: parentEventId

attributes.definition: The grouped version of the URL in the browser at the start of the interaction.
attributes.name: previousGroupedUrl

attributes.definition: The route name of the page at the start of the interaction. This is the last value passed by setCurrentRouteName before the start of the interaction.
attributes.name: previousRouteName

attributes.definition: The ungrouped URL in the browser at the start of the interaction.
attributes.name: previousURL

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the PageView event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes.

For more information about the Navigation Timing API, see Instrumentation for Browser monitoring.

name: ContainerSample
definition: This event is reported by the New Relic Infrastructure agent. It collects data from all the Docker containers on the host (which may or may not be running). It includes the container's ID, name, image, image name, and metrics about CPU, memory and networking. We take a snapshot of this data every 15 seconds for each container and package it into this event, which is then sent to New Relic. This data appears on the Containers UI page.

attributes.definition: Data space available in the Storage Driver. Only available while using Docker's devicemapper storage driver that is deprecated.

attributes.definition: Total Data space in the Storage Driver. Only available while using Docker's devicemapper storage driver that is deprecated.

attributes.name: StorageMetadataAvailableBytes

attributes.name: StorageMetadataTotalBytes

attributes.definition: The amount of memory used by the container that can be associated precisely with a block on a block device.

name: Deployment
definition: Deployment events occur for changes you decide to follow using the change tracking feature.

attributes.definition: The commit identifier (for example, the Git commit SHA).

attributes.definition: Unique identifier we generate when a marker is created. Alphanumeric IDs are from our newer NerdGraph change tracking feature. Numeric IDs are from our legacy REST API-based feature.
attributes.name: deploymentId

attributes.definition: The type of the deployment (for example, 'BASIC', 'BLUE-GREEN', 'CANARY', 'OTHER', 'ROLLING', or 'SHADOW').
attributes.name: deploymentType

attributes.definition: A description of the deployment.
attributes.name: description

attributes.definition: The globally unique identifier for the New Relic entity that this marker applies to.
attributes.name: entity.guid

attributes.definition: The friendly name for the New Relic entity this marker applies to.

attributes.definition: Username of the deployer or bot that created this deployment.
attributes.name: user

attributes.definition: The version of the deployment (for example, v1.1).
attributes.name: version

name: DistributedTraceSummary
definition: This event contains summary data about a distributed trace and provides an aggregated view of distributed tracing data. DistributedTraceSummary events are generated by New Relic and are triggered by distributed tracing data from agents or the Trace API.

attributes.definition: A comma delimited list of newrelic accountIds that took part in this trace.
attributes.name: accountIds

attributes.definition: The total elapsed time in milliseconds of all backend services in this trace.
attributes.name: backend.duration.ms

attributes.definition: The timestamp of the first span in this trace from a backend entity. In distributed tracing, any events that are not from client-side applications contributed to the backend duration.
attributes.name: backend.timestamp

attributes.definition: The duration of the entire distributed trace, including both backend and client-side entities. the earliest span to the latest.
attributes.name: duration.ms

attributes.definition: The number of unique entities that took part in this trace.
attributes.name: entityCount

attributes.definition: A comma delimited list of entity GUIDs for entities that participated in this trace. These GUIDs are assigned by New Relic for the New Relic-monitored entity (host, application, etc.). Each GUID is stored as a Base64 encoded value.
attributes.name: entityGuids

attributes.definition: The number of events in this distributed trace that were identified as errors.
attributes.name: errorCount

attributes.definition: The name of the trace filter used by the Infinite Tracing trace observer to select this trace.
attributes.name: newRelic.traceFilter.type

attributes.definition: The New Relic account ID that the root entity of this trace reports data to.
attributes.name: root.entity.accountId

attributes.definition: The entity GUID associated with the root entity of this trace.
attributes.name: root.entity.guid

attributes.definition: The name of the root entity of this trace.
attributes.name: root.entity.name

attributes.definition: The elapsed time in milliseconds of the root span of this trace. The root of a distributed trace is the first span, and will have a null value for parent.id.
attributes.name: root.span.duration.ms

attributes.definition: The unique identifier of the root span of this trace. The root of a distributed trace is the first span, and it has a null value for parent.id.
attributes.name: root.span.id

attributes.definition: The name of the root span of this trace.
attributes.name: root.span.name

attributes.definition: The timestamp of the root span of this trace. The root of a distributed trace is the first span, and will have a null value for parent.id.
attributes.name: root.span.timestamp

attributes.definition: The number of events in this distributed trace. Events in a distributed trace can have several event types, including Span, Transaction, and TransactionError.
attributes.name: spanCount

attributes.definition: The timestamp of the root span in this distributed trace.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The unique ID (a randomly generated string) used to identify a single request as it crosses inter- and intra- process boundaries. This ID allows the linking of spans in a distributed trace. Included when distributed tracing is enabled.
attributes.name: trace.id

name: InfrastructureEvent
definition: InfrastructureEvent describes changes (deltas) that occur in a system's live state. When an inventory or system state is added, removed, or changed, Infrastructure will produce an InfrastructureEvent that logs that activity.

attributes.definition: A New Relic category used to organize events in the UI. For example: automation, notification, and service.
attributes.name: category

attributes.definition: A simple classification of the type of change made to the entity: added, modified, or removed.
attributes.name: changeType

attributes.definition: The fully specified name of the item that changed. This is constructed by taking the source and adding one or more additional path elements that uniquely identify the item that changed.
attributes.name: changedPath

attributes.definition: Delta refers to a recorded change in the system. The deltaId is a number used by New Relic to organize incoming inventory change data.
attributes.name: deltaId

attributes.definition: The unique ID of the event, generated by New Relic.
attributes.name: eventId

attributes.definition: The type of infrastructure event. Each format type includes attributes that may be used to render the event in the UI.
attributes.name: format

attributes.definition: The new agent status: disconnected or connected.
attributes.name: newStatus

attributes.definition: If a change is made to the entity, this attribute contains the new value of the inventory that was changed. This will have no value if no change has been made. The value will display approximately 4K bytes of data.
attributes.name: newValue

attributes.definition: If a change is made to the entity, this attribute contains the old value of the inventory that was changed. This will be blank if no change has been made.
attributes.name: oldValue

attributes.definition:
For integrations that use generic event types (like the DatastoreSample event), the provider value specifies the source of the data (the service, or a sub-category of data from that service).

Some events are generic and are used by several integrations. For example, the DatastoreSample event is used by several integrations, including the AWS DynamoDB integration and the AWS RDS integration. In these cases, the provider attribute value represents the source of that attribute. This will usually be the service that data comes from or, for integrations that use several provider values, a certain sub-category of data from that service.

When a provider value is present for a generic event, that event will have additional integration-specific attributes attached to it.

Here’s an example of a NRQL query that returns the attributes present for a DatastoreSample event reported by the AWS RDS integration:

SELECT * from DatastoreSample where provider = 'RdsDbCluster'
attributes.name: provider

attributes.definition: The fully specified origin of this inventory item. This is typically in the form category/plugin, where plugin is the generic word used for the tool that gathered this data.
attributes.name: source

attributes.definition: A summary of the change that happened. Uses a human-friendly string, such as Agent disconnected.
attributes.name: summary

attributes.definition: The type of change to the violation: For example: open or closed.
attributes.name: violationUpdateType

name: JavaScriptError
definition: As JavaScript errors are triggered, we capture details as events. The JavaScriptError event contains information to help you segment errors to understand how they impact performance.

attributes.definition: The text of the HTML element that was clicked when a browser interaction started. Added to BrowserInteraction and any AjaxRequest, JavaScriptError and BrowserTiming events that occurred during that interaction.
attributes.name: actionText

attributes.definition: The identification number for the reporting browser agent.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the application that handled the request as shown in browser monitoring.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asnLongitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asnOrganization

attributes.definition: A unique value generated for each browser interaction captured by the New Relic agent.
attributes.name: browserInteractionId

attributes.definition: An unique identifier generated for a stack trace. The browserStackHash for a stack trace is different across different browsers. An identical stack trace will generate the same identifier.
attributes.name: browserStackHash

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: countryCode

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: mobile, tablet, or desktop.
attributes.name: deviceType

attributes.definition: The domain portion of the request URL.
attributes.name: domain

attributes.definition: The unique identifier of the monitor referenced in New Relic One.
attributes.name: entityGuid

attributes.definition: The error type of the JavaScript Error object. Examples: ReferenceError, SyntaxError, and UncaughtException.
attributes.name: errorClass

attributes.definition: The error message that was delivered.
attributes.name: errorMessage

attributes.definition: A value to indicate whether or not this was the first JS error in the session. Example: true.
attributes.name: firstErrorInSession

attributes.definition: The synthetic monitoring account from which you are running the monitor.
attributes.name: monitorAccountId

attributes.definition: A unique number identifying a particular monitor.
attributes.name: monitorId

attributes.definition: The ID of a single synthetic monitor run, which began at a specific time and originated from a specific location.
attributes.name: monitorJobId

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that was loaded for the PageView, for example: http://www.newrelic.com. This URL does not include query parameters.
attributes.name: pageUrl

attributes.definition: A unique value generated for each interaction with the page. You can use this value to group interactions together.
attributes.name: parentEventId

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the PageView event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes.

In the United States, regions correspond to state codes ; for example, WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes .
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: The releases in which the app was updated. Example: {\"jQuery\":\"v3.1.1\",\"multiverse\":\"96e9ac7\"}.
attributes.name: releaseIds

attributes.definition: The URI of the requested resource.
attributes.name: requestUri

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single session. The session cookie expires when the user closes the browser (for example, they fully exit Chrome.) A new session identifier will be assigned when the user opens up a new instance of the browser.
attributes.name: session

attributes.definition: Allows for linking together end user actions from session traces and querying across browser events. Not all browser events will have this. For example, PageView events complete before the first session trace harvest. Also, initial page loads from BrowserInteraction won't always include this.
attributes.name: sessionTraceId

attributes.definition: A unique identifier generated by the Browser agent for a stack trace. The stackHash for a stack trace is the same across different browsers. An identical stack trace will generate the same identifier.
attributes.name: stackHash

attributes.definition: A collection of the active stack frames when the error occurred.
attributes.name: stackTrace

attributes.definition: A compressed version of the stackTrace attribute.
attributes.name: stackTraceGzip

attributes.definition: The time that the error occurred, in Unix time.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The full metric name of the transaction in which the error occurred, or Unknown if the error occurs outside of a transaction.
attributes.name: transactionName

attributes.definition: The browser’s name, such as Chrome and Firefox, obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentName

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported operating system, such as Windows or Linux, that it is running on. This is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentOS

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported software version, which is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentVersion

name: Metric
definition: Represents a metric data point (a measurement over a range of time, or a sample at a specific point in time) with multiple attributes attached, which allow for in-depth analysis and querying. This metric data comes from our Metric API, our Telemetry SDKs, network performance monitoring, and some of our open-source exporters/integrations.

attributes.definition: The end of the time range associated with the metric, in Unix time, in milliseconds. This is calculated by adding the metric interval to the timestamp of the metric (timestamp + interval.ms).
attributes.name: endTimestamp

attributes.definition: The length of the time window.
attributes.name: interval.ms

attributes.definition: Name of the metric.
attributes.name: metricName

attributes.definition: The source of this data. For example: metricAPI.
attributes.name: newrelic.source

attributes.definition: The start time for the metric, in Unix time.
attributes.name: timestamp

name: Mobile
definition: A Mobile event is created when a crash occurs, when an interaction ends or has run for 1 second, or if a session completes after the app is closed, backgrounded, or has run for 10 minutes. Mobile events were once the only event type and were generated for every event, but now there are several specialized event types. Recommendation: Upgrade to the most recent mobile monitoring agent version to take full advantage of the new event types.

attributes.definition: The network over which the app transferred data, such as Wi-Fi, Verizon, or Sprint.
attributes.name: carrier

attributes.definition: The type of data: session, crash, or interaction.
attributes.name: category

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The country from which the device ran the application. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: countryCode

attributes.definition: The specific type of the device: iPhone 8, iPad Pro, etc. Duplicate of deviceType.
attributes.name: device

attributes.definition: The category of the device, such as iPhone or Tablet.
attributes.name: deviceGroup

attributes.definition: The manufacturer of the device, such as Motorola or HTC.
attributes.name: deviceManufacturer

attributes.definition: The model number of the device, such as XT1039 or SM-G900F.
attributes.name: deviceModel

attributes.definition: The device's name.
attributes.name: deviceName

attributes.definition: The specific type of device: iPhone 8, iPad Pro, etc. Duplicate of device.
attributes.name: deviceType

attributes.definition: A unique identifier assigned at the time of app installation by New Relic. It is only reset if a user deletes and then reinstalls the app. For example: B8B0BC30-0235-11E4-9191-0800200C9A66. Duplicate of uuid.
attributes.name: deviceUuid

attributes.definition: For interaction category events only. This is the total time for the interaction to render on the device. In addition to render time, this usually includes all external calls associated with the interaction. Currently, this attribute is measured in seconds for Android devices and in milliseconds for iOS devices.
attributes.name: interactionDuration

attributes.definition: The last interaction before a crash or harvest event, if one is present.
attributes.name: lastInteraction

attributes.definition: For interaction category events only. This is the label of the interaction associated with the event. It is by default assigned by New Relic. For example: ApplicationsListFragment or Display iOS_Example.MasterViewController.
attributes.name: name

attributes.definition: For Android only. The specific build of the Android OS.
attributes.name: osBuild

attributes.definition: The specific region within a country where the monitored app is located. In the United States, regions are states. The regionCode is based on IP address and may not always match your region.
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: The UTC based timestamp for when the event was sent to New Relic. This is different from the attribute ‘timestamp’, which is when the event began.
attributes.name: reportedTimestampMs

attributes.definition: The time, in seconds, from the beginning of the mobile session to the time the event occurred.
attributes.name: timeSinceLoad

attributes.definition: The UTC epoch time at which an event began.
attributes.name: timestamp

name: MobileCrash
definition: The MobileCrash event is created when an app crashes. MobileCrash includes attributes such as crash line number, class, and crash message.

attributes.definition: Indicates the technical build number of the app binary. As a developer, you can use this attribute to identify specific builds of your app.
attributes.name: appBuild

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a monitored app, based on the app token. For example: 35091.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the monitored app. For example: My Mobile App - iOS.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: The version number of the monitored app. For example: 2.2.9.
attributes.name: appVersion

attributes.definition: An identifier for the specific version of the app. For example: 1713477.
attributes.name: appVersionId

attributes.definition: The processor architecture of the device. For example: armv7 or arm64.
attributes.name: architecture

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The version number of the agent running on the application. For example: 4.232.0. Duplicate of newRelicAgentVersion.
attributes.name: newRelicVersion

attributes.definition: The simplified version number of the app's host operating system, such as iOS 11, as compared to iOS 11.0.4.
attributes.name: osMajorVersion

attributes.definition: The name of the app's host operating system, for example, iOS or Android.
attributes.name: osName

attributes.definition: The exact version number of the app's host operating system, such as iOS 11.0.4, as compared to iOS 11.
attributes.name: osVersion

attributes.definition: The platform type of the mobile monitoring agent, such as native or Cordova.
attributes.name: platform

attributes.definition: The specific region within a country where the monitored app is located. In the United States, regions are states. The regionCode is based on IP address and may not always match your region.
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: A boolean value indicating whether or not that session crashed.
attributes.name: sessionCrashed

attributes.definition:
The length of time for which the user used the application in seconds. If the session crashes, sessionDuration is not captured (although other events and attributes are still recorded).

For sessions longer than 10 minutes, events in the Interaction and Custom event categories are sent to New Relic while the session is ongoing, and therefore do not have sessionDuration attributes. Events recorded near the end of the session will include the duration, as will the Session event category.
attributes.name: sessionDuration

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single user session. A new sessionId is created each time the app is brought into the foreground.
attributes.name: sessionId

attributes.definition: The time, in seconds, from the beginning of the mobile session to the time the event occurred.
attributes.name: timeSinceLoad

attributes.definition: The UTC epoch time at which an event began.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: Indictates previous version number only if this is the first launch after app upgrade.
attributes.name: upgradeFrom

attributes.definition: A unique identifier assigned by New Relic for a specific app on a particular device. It is only reset if a user deletes and then reinstalls the app. For example: B8B0BC30-0235-11E4-9191-0800200C9A66. Dupliate of deviceUuid.
attributes.name: uuid

name: NetworkSample
definition: NetworkSample event captures the descriptive and state information for each network device associated with a server. It includes the device's interface and address information, as well as current usage data. New Relic samples this data every 10 seconds for each attached network interface and packages it into a NetworkSample event, then sends the raw data to New Relic's collectors every 60 seconds.

attributes.definition: The name of the agent (Infrastructure).
attributes.name: agentName

attributes.definition: The version of the New Relic Infrastructure agent.
attributes.name: agentVersion

attributes.definition: The number of times that alert conditions violated critical thresholds, causing critical violations and opening incidents. If this attribute does not exist on the sample, it has zero violations.
attributes.name: criticalViolationCount

attributes.definition: New Relic's unique ID number for the entity that is reporting data. This is used by New Relic to distinguish between customers and their entities.
attributes.name: entityID

attributes.definition: The fully qualified (DNS) hostname.
attributes.name: fullHostname

attributes.definition: The unique hardware address of the interface.
attributes.name: hardwareAddress

attributes.definition: The short version of the entity's name.
attributes.name: hostname

attributes.definition: The interface name as reported by the operating system.
attributes.name: interfaceName

attributes.definition: The IP version 4 address.
attributes.name: ipV4Address

attributes.definition: The IP version 6 address.
attributes.name: ipV6Address

attributes.definition:
The Linux kernel version, in string format.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Linux platform.
attributes.name: kernelVersion

attributes.definition:
The name of the Linux distribution the server is using.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Linux platform.
attributes.name: linuxDistribution

attributes.definition: The operating system on which the agent is installed.
attributes.name: operatingSystem

attributes.definition: The number of bytes per second received during the sampling period.
attributes.name: receiveBytesPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of received packets per second dropped during the sampling period.
attributes.name: receiveDroppedPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of receive errors per second on the interface during the sampling period.
attributes.name: receiveErrorsPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of packets per second (as defined by OS) received during the sampling period.
attributes.name: receivePacketsPerSecond

attributes.definition: The state of the entity: either up or down.
attributes.name: state

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The number of bytes sent per second during the sampling period.
attributes.name: transmitBytesPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of dropped send packets per second during the sampling period.
attributes.name: transmitDroppedPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of send errors per second on the interface during the sampling period.
attributes.name: transmitErrorsPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of packets per second as defined by OS) sent during this sampling period.
attributes.name: transmitPacketsPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of times that alert conditions violated warning thresholds, causing warning violations.
attributes.name: warningViolationCount

attributes.definition:
The Windows family indicates whether the OS is a server or desktop targeted system.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Windows platform.
attributes.name: windowsFamily

attributes.definition:
The full product name of the installed version of Windows.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Windows platform.
attributes.name: windowsPlatform

attributes.definition:
The combined Windows version and build-number string of the OS.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Windows platform.
attributes.name: windowsVersion

name: NrAiIncident
definition: An NrAiIncident is created when violation of an alerts condition generates a violation event, which passes important information downstream.

attributes.definition:
The ID of the account where the violation occurred.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: accountId

attributes.definition: The active condition's aggregation window.
attributes.name: aggregationDuration

attributes.definition:
If applicable, what caused the incident to close. Available values:

  • CONDITION_DELETED: condition deleted.
  • CONDITION_DISABLED condition disabled.
  • CONDITION_MODIFIED condition edited
  • EVALUATOR: natural close because the metric has ceased to breach the threshold.
  • EXPIRED: incident closed due to TTL.
  • INCIDENT_WORKFLOW_INTEGRATION: a third party closed the issue or incident through an API call.
  • LABEL_BINDINGS_CHANGED : label was removed from the target, causing it to no longer be covered by the condition. This only applies to APM/Mobile/Browser/Infrastructure conditions.
  • LOSS_OF_SIGNAL: signal was lost, and incident was closed based on loss of signal settings.
  • MAINTENANCE: New Relic was performing maintenance and we closed the incident as part of it.
  • POLICY_DELETED: policy was deleted.
  • TARGET_REMOVED: the target was removed from the condition.
  • USER: closed manually by a user.
attributes.name: closeCause

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the incident was closed.
attributes.name: closeTime

attributes.definition: If true, open violations on the signal are closed if the signal is lost. Default is false. To use this field, an expirationDuration must be specified.
attributes.name: closeViolationsOnExpiration

attributes.definition:
The ID of the condition that triggered the violation.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: conditionId

attributes.definition:
The name of the condition that triggered the violation.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: conditionName

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the targeted metric started to breach the active condition’s threshold.
attributes.name: degradationTime

attributes.definition:
The contents of the active condition’s Violation Description field.

NRQL or Infrastructure conditions only.
attributes.name: description

attributes.definition: The GUID, assigned by New Relic, for the New Relic-monitored entity (host, application, etc.). This value is stored as a Base64 encoded value.
attributes.name: entity.guid

attributes.definition: The targeted entity's name, if available.
attributes.name: entity.name

attributes.definition: The targeted entity's type, if available.
attributes.name: entity.type

attributes.definition: The active condition's evaluation offset. A time delay (in seconds) to ensure data points are placed in the correct aggregation window.
attributes.name: evaluationOffsetSeconds

attributes.definition:
The reason the violation was opened. Available values:

  • threshold (the condition threshold was breached)
  • expiration (the entity's signal was lost)
  • anomaly (an automatic anomaly was generated)
attributes.name: evaluationType

attributes.definition:
The record's event type.

Available values: Open and Close.
attributes.name: event

attributes.definition: The active condition's signal loss time window.
attributes.name: expirationDuration

attributes.definition: The unique identifier of the violation.
attributes.name: incidentId

attributes.definition: Shows whether the active condition was muted at the time of the incident event.
attributes.name: muted

attributes.definition: The unqiue identifier of the muting rule that caused the violation to be muted.
attributes.name: mutingRuleId

attributes.definition:
The type of data targeted by a NRQL condition. In this context, this refers to any NRQL-queryable data type.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: nrqlEventType

attributes.definition:
The full string of the NRQL query. Can be used for sub-string matching on attributes in the WHERE clause.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: nrqlQuery

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the violation was opened.
attributes.name: openTime

attributes.definition:
The violation threshold's operator, such as =, <, or >.

For signal loss violations, this is an empty string.
attributes.name: operator

attributes.definition:
The ID of the policy that triggered the violation.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: policyId

attributes.definition:
The name of the policy that triggered the violation.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: policyName

attributes.definition: The incident's priority: low, medium, high, or critical. Default: high.
attributes.name: priority

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the active condition's targeted metric stops breaching the threshold.
attributes.name: recoveryTime

attributes.definition:
The runbook URL for the condition that triggered the violation.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: runbookUrl

attributes.definition:
Arbitrary key-value metadata, or tags, associated with the violation. tags. is the prefix and * is the metadata/tag name. For details on how to use this, see the documentation for muting rules or alerts condition descriptions.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: tags.*

attributes.definition:
The name of the violation’s target. This can be an entity or a query.

Available for muting rules.
attributes.name: targetName

attributes.definition: The active condition's threshold value.
attributes.name: threshold

attributes.definition: The active condition's threshold time window.
attributes.name: thresholdDuration

attributes.definition: Shows whether for at least or at least once in occurrence values are being used in the active condition's threshold. Available values: all or any.
attributes.name: thresholdOccurrences

attributes.definition: The event's wall clock time using an epoch timestamp.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The incident's title.
attributes.name: title

attributes.definition:
The incident's type.

Available values: Incident.
attributes.name: type

attributes.definition:
The active condition's aggregation function.

Used in APM, browser, and mobile alert condition types.
attributes.name: valueFunction

attributes.definition: The active condition's violation time limit setting.
attributes.name: violationTimeLimitSeconds

attributes.definition: Deprecated. Do not use.
attributes.name: violationUuId

name: NrAiIncidentExternal
definition: An NrAiIncidentExternal event is created when a custom incident event is received via the incident event API.

attributes.definition:
The aggregationTag attribute has a unique suffix added to it. Any events with aggregationTag and the same suffix value are grouped together in an incident. A resolve event resets this aggregation grouping.

When resolving an incident, make sure the resolve event includes the same aggregation tag.
attributes.name: aggregationTag.*

attributes.definition: A URL to a page related to the incident.
attributes.name: deepLinkUrl

attributes.definition: The triggering event description.
attributes.name: description

attributes.definition: The GUID, assigned by New Relic, for the New Relic-monitored entity (host, application, etc.). This value is stored as a Base64 encoded value.
attributes.name: entity.guid

attributes.definition: The incident's priority: low, medium, high, or critical. Default: high.
attributes.name: priority

attributes.definition: The runbook URL for the condition that triggered the violation.
attributes.name: runbookUrl

attributes.definition: The system that triggered the notification, not the entity that faulted. Required for trigger.
attributes.name: source

attributes.definition: Whether the event should trigger a new incident or resolve an existing one. The values can be trigger, resolve, or acknowledge. Required.
attributes.name: state

attributes.definition: Arbitrary key-value metadata, or tags, associated with the violation. tag is the prefix and * is the metadata/tag name.
attributes.name: tag.*

attributes.definition: The event's wall clock time using an epoch timestamp.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The triggering event title. Required for trigger.
attributes.name: title

attributes.definition: The version of the current format.
attributes.name: version

name: NrAiIssue
definition: An NrAiIssue is created when a threshold of an alert condition generates an incident event, which passes important information downstream.

attributes.definition: ID of the account where incidents occurred.
attributes.name: accountIds

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the issue was activated.
attributes.name: activateTime

attributes.definition:
What caused the incident to close. Available values:

  • CLOSED_BY_ISSUE: Issue in a created state that closed naturally before activation.

  • CLOSED_BY_USER: Issue in a created state that the user closes before activation.

  • CLOSE_INACTIVE: Issue reached 5000 (max) incidents.

  • closeTtl: Issue closed due to issue TTL (issue settings).

  • CONDITION_DELETED: Condition deleted.

  • CONDITION_DISABLED: Condition disabled.

  • CONDITION_MODIFIED: Condition edited.

  • EVALUATOR: Natural close because the metric has ceased to breach the threshold.

  • EXPIRED: Incident closed due to TTL.

  • INCIDENT_CLOSED: The issue contains only anomalies and is closed when the last anomaly is closed.

  • LOSS_OF_SIGNAL: Signal was lost, and incident was closed based on loss of signal settings.

  • POLICY_DELETED: Policy was deleted.

  • TARGET_REMOVED: The target was removed from the condition.

  • thirdPartyIntegration: A third party closed the issue through an API call.

  • USER: Closed manually by a user on the legacy version.

  • userAction: Closed manually by a user.
attributes.name: closeCause

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the incident was closed.
attributes.name: closeTime

attributes.definition: Indicates whether the issue was correlated (true/false).
attributes.name: correlated

attributes.definition: Indicates whether the issue was a correlated candidate (true/false).
attributes.name: correlatedCandidate

attributes.definition: The unique identifier of the correlation rule.
attributes.name: correlationRuleIds

attributes.definition: The name of the correlation rule.
attributes.name: correlationRuleNames

attributes.definition: The timestamp when the issue was created.
attributes.name: createTime

attributes.definition: Number of impacted entities.
attributes.name: entitiesCount

attributes.definition: The name of the targeted entity.
attributes.name: entity.names

attributes.definition: The type of the targeted entity.
attributes.name: entity.types

attributes.definition: The event type of the record.
attributes.name: event

attributes.definition: Number of incidents in the issue.
attributes.name: incidentCount

attributes.definition: The unique identifiers of the issue's incidents.
attributes.name: incidentIds

attributes.definition: Indicates whether the issue is idle (true/false).
attributes.name: isIdle

attributes.definition: The unique identifier of the issue.
attributes.name: issueId

attributes.definition: Link to the issue page.
attributes.name: issueLink

attributes.definition: The timestamp of the last modification.
attributes.name: lastModifiedTime

attributes.definition: Shows whether the active condition was muted at the time of the incident event.
attributes.name: muted

attributes.definition: The unique identifier of the parent issue.
attributes.name: parentId

attributes.definition: The incident's priority: low, medium, high, or critical. Default: high.
attributes.name: priority

attributes.definition: If applicable, the source of the issue.
attributes.name: sources

attributes.definition: The wall clock time of the event using an epoch timestamp.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The incident's title.
attributes.name: title

name: NrAiSignal
definition: NrAiSignal shows details from every NRQL alert condition and every signal on your account, for every aggregation window that passes. This data is posted immediately after each aggregation window is aggregated and evaluated, so it will show you exactly what our alerts are seeing.

attributes.definition: Count of the number of data points that were aggregated for this window.
attributes.name: aggregatedDataPointsCount

attributes.definition: Duration of the aggregation window of the active condition, in seconds.
attributes.name: aggregationDuration

attributes.definition: ID of the active condition.
attributes.name: conditionId

attributes.definition: Moment when this event was created, and the end of the aggregation window.
attributes.name: endTimestamp

attributes.definition: The GUID, assigned by New Relic, for the New Relic-monitored entity (host, application, etc.). This value is stored as a Base64 encoded value.
attributes.name: entity.guid

attributes.definition: Type of the active entity. Note that NA indicates an infrastructure entity.
attributes.name: entity.type

attributes.definition: This captures any errors when evaluating the signal.
attributes.name: error

attributes.definition:
The type of event captured in this data point.

  • Value: A single value was evaluated (most common).
  • Expiration: A signal loss is detected.
  • Reset: Indicates a detail of the condition was changed, and the signal has been reset.
attributes.name: event

attributes.definition: Duration of the loss of signal of the active condition.
attributes.name: expirationDuration

attributes.definition: Exclusively for expiration events, it's the wall-clock time of the last data point received.
attributes.name: expirationLastSeenTime

attributes.definition: Gap-filling setting from the active condition.
attributes.name: fillOption

attributes.definition: For baseline conditions only. Indicates the number of standard deviations between the actual value and the predicted value. Formally called z-score or standard score.
attributes.name: numberOfDeviations

attributes.definition: For baseline conditions only. Indicates the value that our models predicted for this data point.
attributes.name: predictedValue

attributes.definition:
For reset events only. Available values:

  • New: It's a new signal coming online.
  • Expired: Signal reset due to loss of signal configuration.
  • ConditionDisabled: The user disabled the condition in the UI.
  • delayedEvaluation: The condition has a delayed evaluation configured. Therefore, New Relic sends resets through the system to prevent evaluation before the expected time.
  • Suppression: Because of an ongoing incident, alerts are suppressed.
  • Interrupt: When we detect issues, we internally interrupt our services. Issues are mainly out-of-order data points that can cause false alerts.
  • ConditionDeleted: The user has deleted the condition in the UI.
  • ConditionModified: The user has modified the condition in a way that requires re-registration on our side.
  • PolicyDeleted: Deleted the entire policy.
  • User: The user has closed the incident manually in the UI.
attributes.name: resetCause

attributes.definition: New Relic’s server clock time when the data point was evaluated.
attributes.name: serverTime

attributes.definition: Unique identifier for this data stream.
attributes.name: signalId

attributes.definition: Value of the signal for this aggregation window.
attributes.name: signalValue

attributes.definition: For sliding windows conditions only. Duration of the slide-by interval, in seconds.
attributes.name: slideByDuration

attributes.definition: Tells you how closely the signal value and the baseline prediction track each other: Standard deviation will be low when they track each other closely, and high when they don't. This attribute uses the same units as the signal.
attributes.name: standardDeviation

attributes.definition: All the system and custom tags that have been added to a signal.
attributes.name: tags.<TagName>

attributes.definition: The start of the aggregation window.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: Always = “signal”.
attributes.name: type

name: NrAuditEvent
definition: An NrAuditEvent is created by New Relic services to record configuration changes made in New Relic products. The data gathered for this event includes the type of account change, actor (user or API key) that made the change, a human-readable description of the action taken, and a timestamp for the change.

attributes.definition:
Indicates an action that was taken in a New Relic account.

The actionIdentifier attribute describes the action that was taken. Some actionIdentifier values will be prefixed by the targetType.

Some examples of actionIdentifier values:

  • account.update_owner
  • alerts.condition.create
  • alerts.condition.update
  • alerts.condition.delete
  • alerts.condition.unarchive
  • role.create
  • user.add_roles
  • user.add_to_account
  • user.invite_to_account
  • user.remove_from_account
  • user.remove_roles
  • synthetics_monitor.create
  • synthetics_monitor.delete
attributes.name: actionIdentifier

attributes.definition: ID of the API key taking action. The API key is partially obfuscated to ensure privacy of the key.
attributes.name: actorAPIKey

attributes.definition: Email address for the person who made the change.
attributes.name: actorEmail

attributes.definition: ID of the person taking action.
attributes.name: actorId

attributes.definition: The IP address for the person or API key where the action initiated.
attributes.name: actorIpAddress

attributes.definition:
Identifies whether the action was initiated by a user (person) or with an API key that is not associated with a user.

  • user: For greatest data accuracy, select user, along with actorId and actorEmail.
  • api_key: If used, the actorId and actorEmail are not required
attributes.name: actorType

attributes.definition: Human-readable description of the action taken. For example: Added name@company.com to roles Browser manager.
attributes.name: description

attributes.definition: Unique ID of the audit event.
attributes.name: id

attributes.definition: The corresponding account ID for the 'scopeType'.
attributes.name: scopeId

attributes.definition: Uses the value 'account'.
attributes.name: scopeType

attributes.definition: ID of the object (targetType) that changed. For example, if the targetType is a user, this is the person's New Relic user ID.
attributes.name: targetId

attributes.definition: The object that changed; for example, account, role, user, alert conditions or notifications, logs, etc.
attributes.name: targetType

attributes.definition:
Time that the event occurred or was evaluated over. Specifies a time or range of time. Examples:

  • MM-DD-YYYY HH:MM:SS
  • SINCE 2018-05-28 11:18:45
  • UNTIL 30 minutes ago
  • SINCE '2018-06-20' UNTIL today
attributes.name: timestamp

name: NrConsumption
definition: This event records usage every hour, and is the equivalent of "real-time" usage. Use this event to observe usage trends over time. For aggregate views of usage across an entire billing period, use NrMTDConsumption.

attributes.definition: The number of bytes ingested by the consuming account via either an agent, a custom event API, or another integration.
attributes.name: BytesIngested

attributes.definition: The number of core users.
attributes.name: CoreUsers

attributes.definition: The number of full platform users.
attributes.name: FullUsers

attributes.definition: The amount of data ingested by the consuming account.
attributes.name: GigabytesIngested

attributes.definition: ID of the New Relic account that's directly responsible for the stored data, as determined from the license key.
attributes.name: consumingAccountId

attributes.definition: Name of the New Relic account directly responsible for the stored data, as determined from the license key.
attributes.name: consumingAccountName

attributes.definition: The amount of consumption converted to the unit of pricing. For example, for Data Platform, consumption is equal to GigabytesIngested. For Full Stack Observability, consumption is equal to FullUsers. This attribute is useful if you want to see consumption faceted by productLine or other attribute.
attributes.name: consumption

attributes.definition: A cost estimate based on your usage. This is an estimate, not an actual invoiced amount. To be deprecated in May of 2022.
attributes.name: estimatedCost

attributes.definition:
The ID of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountId is the consumingAccountId. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountId

attributes.definition:
Name of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events, or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountName is the same as consumingAccountName. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountName

attributes.definition: Consolidates multiple categories of usage into a single metric. Helpful when faceting by productLine.
attributes.name: metric

attributes.definition: The month and year during which the consumption occurred. Example: August 2020.
attributes.name: month

attributes.definition: The timestamp of the month during which the consumption occurred.
attributes.name: monthTimestamp

attributes.definition: The New Relic product the usage data is from. Use this attribute to identify / filter for product specific usage data.
attributes.name: productLine

attributes.definition: UNIX timestamp (seconds since epoch) of the day and time when event generation was initiated.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The underlying NrUsage metric that resulted in the consumption. For example, GigabytesIngested consumption may be made up of ApmEventBytes, BrowserEventBytes, CustomEventBytes and other NrUsage metrics.
attributes.name: usageMetric

name: NrDailyUsage
definition: Once per day, New Relic products generate a NrDailyUsage event. Use the productLine attribute to identify and filter for the specific product's usage.

attributes.definition:
ID reported by the agent to uniquely identify the host for which this usage event is reported.

This value can come from several sources in the application's environment, but commonly is the value returned by the gethostname Linux syscall. In Docker environments, this attribute can take on the value (sometimes truncated) of the Docker container ID. agentHostname is one of three possible providers for the hostId value.
attributes.name: agentHostname

attributes.definition: Bytes of RAM available to the host, as detected by the New Relic agent from the host OS.
attributes.name: apmAgentMemoryBytes

attributes.definition: Number of logical CPU cores available to the host, as detected by the New Relic agent from the host OS.
attributes.name: apmAgentProcessorCount

attributes.definition:
Version of the New Relic APM agent running in the application instance reporting this usage.

Present only for events where usageType equals Application. To update your agent version, see Update the New Relic agent.
attributes.name: apmAgentVersion

attributes.definition: ID uniquely identifying the application that is reporting this usage, as it appears in the APM product. Present only for events where usageType equals Application.
attributes.name: apmAppId

attributes.definition: ID uniquely identifying the application instance (the process running the New Relic APM agent).
attributes.name: apmAppInstanceId

attributes.definition: Name of the application reporting this usage, as it appears in the APM product. Present only for events where usageType equals Application.
attributes.name: apmAppName

attributes.definition:
Size of the host, for CU-based billing purposes.

Calculated as apmProcessorCount plus (apmMemoryBytes/(1024^3)), or the number of processors plus memory (GiB).
attributes.name: apmBillingInstanceSize

attributes.definition: Bytes of RAM available to the host, as defined by the cloud provider for the host's instance type.
attributes.name: apmCloudDerivedMemoryBytes

attributes.definition: Number of logical processors available to the host, as defined by the cloud provider for the host's instance type.
attributes.name: apmCloudDerivedProcessorCount

attributes.definition:
Describes the algorithm used to calculate the host size for CU usage.

Values include:

  • agent_collected_calculated_data: Use the host size data collected by the agent from the OS environment.
  • cloud_provider_data: Use the host size data from the cloud provider.
  • missing_data: Some host size data was missing. This could be due to an older agent that doesn't support reporting CPU and memory sizes, or an agent and OS combination for which CPU and memory sizes are not supported. This will result in the default host size (16) being applied.
attributes.name: apmComputeUnitRule

attributes.definition:
Number of compute units (CUs) recorded for the given host.

CUs are calculated as apmHoursUsed multiplied by apmBillingInstanceSize. For more information, see Compute unit pricing.
attributes.name: apmComputeUnits

attributes.definition: The number of unique container IDs associated with this host. Present only for events where usageType equals Host.
attributes.name: apmContainerCount

attributes.definition:
Number of hours for which usage was recorded for the given entity.

When an entity is connected to New Relic for any amount of time within a given hour, that hour is counted toward usage. When calculating monthly APM host usage, the calculation for equivalent hosts for a month assumes that a standard month has 750 hours: `apmHoursUsed / 750`.
attributes.name: apmHoursUsed

attributes.definition:
Name of the language that the usage-reporting application is written in, as reported by the New Relic agent.

Examples: ruby, java, python. Present only for events where usageType equals Application.
attributes.name: apmLanguage

attributes.definition:
Bytes of RAM available to the host. Used to calculate apmBillingInstanceSize.

The value of one of these attributes will be used: apmCloudDerivedMemoryBytes, apmAgentMemoryBytes.
attributes.name: apmMemoryBytes

attributes.definition:
Number of logical processors available to the host, used to calculate apmBillingInstanceSize.

The value of one of these attributes will be used: apmCloudDerivedProcessorCount, apmAgentProcessorCount.
attributes.name: apmProcessorCount

attributes.definition:
Linux boot ID of host for which this usage is reported, which is unique for each boot lifetime of each Linux operating system instance.

Will only be present when the New Relic agent is one of the following versions: Go: 1.11 or higher Java: 3.42.0 or higher .NET: 6.19.330.0 or higher Node.js: 2.1.0 or higher PHP: 7.5.0.199 or higher Python: 2.90.0.75 or higher Ruby: 4.4.0.336 or higher bootId is one of three possible providers for the hostId value.
attributes.name: bootId

attributes.definition: ID uniquely identifying the application reporting this usage, as it appears in the Browser product. Deprecated.
attributes.name: browserAppId

attributes.definition:
Number of page views for an application for that 24-hour period.

For more on how events are generated, see Data generation. Page views for both Pro and Lite Browser agents are counted.
attributes.name: browserPageViewCount

attributes.definition:
ID uniquely identifying the cloud host instance (example: an AWS EC2 instance) for which this usage is reported.

(For example, for an AWS EC2 instance, the value would look like i-1234abcd5678ef900.) This is used to uniquely identify the host if the apmComputeUnitRule is cloud_provider_data. This will not be present if no cloud provider was detected by the agent. Agents with these versions will detect cloud provider data for AWS: Go: 1.11 or higher Java: 3.18.0 or higher .NET: 5.1.72.0 or higher Node.js: 1.21.0 or higher PHP: 5.5.0 or higher Python: 2.54.0.41 or higher Ruby: 3.12.1.298 or higher cloudInstanceId is one of three possible providers for the hostId value.
attributes.name: cloudInstanceId

attributes.definition:
Size of the cloud instance for this host for CU-based APM billing purposes.

This is calculated according to the formula for apmBillingInstanceSize, using the CPU and memory sizes associated with the instance type defined by the cloud provider. Will not be present if no cloud provider was detected by the agent.
attributes.name: cloudInstanceSize

attributes.definition:
Instance type of the host as defined by the cloud provider and detected by the agent.

For example: c4.2xlarge. This will not be present if no cloud provider was detected by the agent.
attributes.name: cloudInstanceType

attributes.definition: Name of the cloud provider for this host. Example values: aws, azure. This will not be present if no cloud provider was detected by the agent.
attributes.name: cloudProvider

attributes.definition:
Name of the zone that a cloud provider host is located in.

For example: eu-central-1b. This will not be present if no cloud provider was detected by the agent.
attributes.name: cloudZone

attributes.definition: ID of the New Relic account that's directly responsible for the stored data, as determined from the license key.
attributes.name: consumingAccountId

attributes.definition: Name of the New Relic account directly responsible for the stored data, as determined from the license key.
attributes.name: consumingAccountName

attributes.definition:
ID of the Docker or other Linux container in which the application instance is running.

This will not be present if a container was not detected by the agent. Present only for events where usageType equals Application. This attribute is not used to uniquely identify hosts for billing purposes.
attributes.name: containerId

attributes.definition:
ID used to uniquely identify the host for which this usage is reported.

Any given hour of APM usage for this host will be counted only once when calculating apmHoursUsed. There are several possible host identifiers reported by the New Relic agent. The attributes, if present, will be chosen to use in this order of precedence: cloudInstanceId, bootId, agentHostname.
attributes.name: hostId

attributes.definition: Bytes of RAM available to the host, used to calculate infrastructureBillingInstanceSize.
attributes.name: infrastructureAgentMemoryBytes

attributes.definition: Number of logical CPU cores available to the host, used to calculate infrastructureBillingInstanceSize.
attributes.name: infrastructureAgentProcessorCount

attributes.definition:
Version of the Infrastructure agent running on the host reporting this usage.

If multiple agents are reporting from the same host, the version from the first agent seen in a given hour will be used.
attributes.name: infrastructureAgentVersion

attributes.definition: Size of the host, for CU billing purposes. Calculated as: number of processors multiplied by memory in gibibytes (GiB).
attributes.name: infrastructureBillingInstanceSize

attributes.definition: Bytes of RAM available to the host, as reported by the cloud provider, used to calculate infrastructureBillingInstanceSize.
attributes.name: infrastructureCloudDerivedMemoryBytes

attributes.definition: Number of logical CPU cores available to the host, as reported by the cloud provider, used to calculate infrastructureBillingInstanceSize.
attributes.name: infrastructureCloudDerivedProcessorCount

attributes.definition:
Describes the algorithm used to calculate the host size for CU usage.

Values include: agent_collected_calculated_data: Use the host size data collected by the agent from the OS environment. cloud_provider_data: Use the host size data from the cloud provider. missing_data: Some host size data was missing. This could be due to an agent and operating system combination for which CPU and memory sizes are not supported. This will result in the default host size (16) being applied.
attributes.name: infrastructureComputeUnitRule

attributes.definition:
Number of compute units (CUs) recorded for the given host.
