CUs are calculated as: infrastructureHoursUsed multiplied by infrastructureBillingInstanceSize. For more about compute unit calculation, see Compute unit pricing.
attributes.name: infrastructureComputeUnits

attributes.definition: Number of hours for which usage was recorded for the given host. When a host is connected to New Relic for any amount of time within a given hour, that hour is counted toward usage.
attributes.name: infrastructureHoursUsed

attributes.definition: The type of event. For example: Transaction, MobileCrash, or SystemSample. Event namespaces are associated with a specific data retention period.
attributes.name: insightsEventNamespace

attributes.definition:
Count of all events of the given insightsEventNamespace stored for the retention period included with a paid non-Insights product subscription.

For example, APM Pro subscriptions include several days' retention of Transaction events. This attribute represents a count of events existing in storage as measured on a given day, and not a count of the events added to storage during a given day. Summing this attribute over a period of more than a day may not give you what you expect; for example, it will not yield the total volume of events written to storage in that period.
attributes.name: insightsIncludedEventCount

attributes.definition:
Number of hours for which events of the given insightsEventNamespace are stored but are not counted toward your paid Insights Pro subscription.

For more information about the data reported in nrDailyUsage, see Insights usage: Attributes and queries.
attributes.name: insightsIncludedRetentionInHours

attributes.definition: New Relic product (Insights, APM, Browser, Mobile, etc.) that corresponds to the given insightsEventNamespace.
attributes.name: insightsNrProduct

attributes.definition:
Count of all events stored for the given insightsEventNamespace as of the given day.

Sum of insightsIncludedEventCount and the number of events stored beyond the retention period included with a paid non-Insights product subscription. This attribute represents a count of events existing in storage as measured on a given day, and not a count of the events added to storage during a given day. Summing this attribute over a period of more than a day may not give you what you expect; for example, it will not yield the total volume of events written to storage in that period.
attributes.name: insightsTotalEventCount

attributes.definition: Number of hours for which events of the given insightsEventNamespace are stored.
attributes.name: insightsTotalRetentionInHours

attributes.definition: This is True if the calculated host size was greater than 16 and therefore capped.
attributes.name: instanceSizeCapped

attributes.definition:
Boolean. true means the application is the primary app. false means the app is one of several apps that an agent reports data for. Deprecated.

For more on multiple app names in APM and Browser, see Use multiple names for an app. The sum of events where this attribute is true will give an accurate total of page views when you are using the multiple app names feature. Counting events where this attribute is false will result in over-counting of usage.
attributes.name: isPrimaryApp

attributes.definition:
The ID of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountId is the consumingAccountId. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountId

attributes.definition:
Name of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events, or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountName is the same as consumingAccountName. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountName

attributes.definition: This is True if the APM agent reports no CPU count.
attributes.name: missingCpuData

attributes.definition: This is True if the APM agent reports no memory count.
attributes.name: missingRamData

attributes.definition: ID uniquely identifying the application reporting this usage, as it appears in the Mobile product.
attributes.name: mobileAppId

attributes.definition: Name of the application reporting this usage, as it appears in the Mobile product.
attributes.name: mobileAppName

attributes.definition: Number of unique users (device IDs) counted during the current calendar month to date for a Mobile app.
attributes.name: mobileUniqueUsersPerMonth

attributes.definition:
Partner ID of the New Relic customer partnership associated with the account responsible for the stored events.

This attribute is only present if the consuming account is associated with a New Relic customer partnership.
attributes.name: partnershipId

attributes.definition:
Name of the New Relic customer partnership associated with the account responsible for the stored events.

This attribute is only present if the consuming account is associated with a customer partnership.
attributes.name: partnershipName

attributes.definition: The New Relic product the usage data is from. Use this attribute to identify / filter for product specific usage data.
attributes.name: productLine

attributes.definition:
ID of the child account (also known as the sub-account) responsible for the stored event. When present, subAccountId is the same as consumingAccountId.

This attribute is only present if the consuming account is a child account (not a parent account).
attributes.name: subAccountId

attributes.definition:
Name of the child account (also known as the sub-account) responsible for stored events. When present, this is the same as consumingAccountName.

This attribute is only present if the consuming account is a child account (not a parent account).
attributes.name: subAccountName

attributes.definition:
Number of failed checks that ran on the given day for the given synthetic monitor and location.

Failed checks count toward subscription usage for synthetics. Only checks with syntheticsType not equal to SIMPLE count toward billable subscription usage.
attributes.name: syntheticsFailedCheckCount

attributes.definition: Location the check ran in.
attributes.name: syntheticsLocation

attributes.definition:
Human-readable label for the location of the check.

For more information about the data reported in nrDailyUsage, see Insights usage: Attributes and queries.
attributes.name: syntheticsLocationLabel

attributes.definition: Unique ID of the monitor.
attributes.name: syntheticsMonitorId

attributes.definition: Name of the monitor.
attributes.name: syntheticsMonitorName

attributes.definition:
Number of successful checks that ran on the given day for the given synthetic monitor and location.

Only checks with syntheticsType not equal to SIMPLE count toward billable subscription usage.
attributes.name: syntheticsSuccessCheckCount

attributes.definition:
The type of Synthetics monitor. Possible values: SIMPLE, BROWSER, SCRIPT_BROWSER, SCRIPT_API.

For more information, see Types of synthetic monitors.
attributes.name: syntheticsType

attributes.definition: Human-readable label for syntheticsType. Possible values: Ping, Simple Browser, Scripted Browser, Scripted API.
attributes.name: syntheticsTypeLabel

attributes.definition: UNIX timestamp (seconds since epoch) of the day and time when event generation was initiated.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition:
For APM, this value can be either Application or Host, depending on the type of entity this event records usage for (other New Relic products will have different values for usageType).

Events with both values are recorded so that usage data can be analyzed in several ways. For Application: the event represents usage for a single unique application instance for that day. For Host: the event represents usage for a single unique host for that day. Only Host entities are used to calculate billable usage. Application entities are useful for comparing usage between applications, but are not used for billing or contract purposes.
attributes.name: usageType

name: NrIntegrationError
definition: The NrIntegrationError event captures error messages related to data ingest, such as exceeding limits or malformed data.

attributes.definition: The first six characters of the API key used for the request that generated an error.
attributes.name: apiKeyPrefix

attributes.definition: The category of the error (for example, EventApiException for custom events).
attributes.name: category

attributes.definition: The HTTP status code associated with the transaction. Some agents use httpResponseCode, which is equivalent.
attributes.name: http.statusCode

attributes.definition: The HTTP response code associated with the transaction. Some agents use http.statusCode, which is equivalent.
attributes.name: httpResponseCode

attributes.definition: Contents of the error message.
attributes.name: message

attributes.definition: The error's name (for example, EventValidationException for custom events).
attributes.name: name

attributes.definition: The name of the feature experiencing errors. For example: Event API, Metrics, or Distributed tracing.
attributes.name: newRelicFeature

attributes.definition: The UUID returned by the API for the request that generated an error.
attributes.name: requestId

attributes.definition: The HTTP response code associated with the transaction.
attributes.name: response.status

name: NrMTDConsumption
definition: This event tracks your New Relic usage (data and billable users) and estimated cost across an entire calendar month. It generates aggregate values from the NrConsumption event.

attributes.definition: The number of bytes ingested by the consuming account via either an agent, a custom event API, or another integration.
attributes.name: BytesIngested

attributes.definition: The number of core users.
attributes.name: CoreUsers

attributes.definition: The number of billable core users.
attributes.name: CoreUsersBillable

attributes.definition: The number of billable full platform users.
attributes.name: FullPlatformUsersBillable

attributes.definition: The number of full platform users within the free limit (if available).
attributes.name: FullPlatformUsersFree

attributes.definition: The number of full platform users.
attributes.name: FullUsers

attributes.definition: The number of billable full platform users.
attributes.name: FullUsersBillable

attributes.definition: The number of full platform users within the free limit (if available).
attributes.name: FullUsersFree

attributes.definition: The amount of data ingested by the consuming account.
attributes.name: GigabytesIngested

attributes.definition: The number of gigabytes ingested by the consuming account that exceed the free limit and are considered billable.
attributes.name: GigabytesIngestedBillable

attributes.definition: The amount of billable consumption in the unit of pricing. For example, for Data Platform, billableConsumption is equal to GigabytesIngestedBillable. For Full Stack Observability, billableConsumption is equal to FullUsersBillable. Estimated cost is equal to billableConsumption multiplied by the unit price of the metric.
attributes.name: billableConsumption

attributes.definition: The amount of consumption converted to the unit of pricing. For example, for Data Platform, consumption is equal to GigabytesIngested. For Full Stack Observability, consumption is equal to FullUsers. This attribute is useful if you want to see consumption faceted by productLine or other attribute.
attributes.name: consumption

attributes.definition: A cost estimate based on your usage. This is an estimate, not an actual invoiced amount. To be deprecated in May of 2022.
attributes.name: estimatedCost

attributes.definition: The amount of consumption that is within the consuming account's free limit.
attributes.name: freeConsumption

attributes.definition: The total amount of consumption included in the free limit. After consumption exceeds this amount billableConsumption begins to accumulate.
attributes.name: freeLimit

attributes.definition:
The ID of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountId is the consumingAccountId. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountId

attributes.definition: Consolidates multiple categories of usage into a single metric. Helpful when faceting by productLine.
attributes.name: metric

attributes.definition: The month and year during which the consumption occurred. Example: August 2020.
attributes.name: month

attributes.definition: The timestamp of the month during which the consumption occurred.
attributes.name: monthTimestamp

attributes.definition: The New Relic product the usage data is from. Use this attribute to identify / filter for product specific usage data.
attributes.name: productLine

attributes.definition: UNIX timestamp (seconds since epoch) of the day and time when event generation was initiated.
attributes.name: timestamp

name: NrUsage
definition: This event records usage every hour and is used to see usage reported per product.

attributes.definition: Used in conjunction with “type” to determine whether usage is aggregated based on sum (sum all usage per hour) or max (take max usage per hour).
attributes.name: aggregationFunction

attributes.definition: The unique numeric identifier assigned by New Relic for the service/app that generated the transaction.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: ID of the New Relic account that's directly responsible for the stored data, as determined from the license key.
attributes.name: consumingAccountId

attributes.definition: Name of the New Relic account directly responsible for the stored data, as determined from the license key.
attributes.name: consumingAccountName

attributes.definition: The aggregation window (for example, 1 hour or 1 day).
attributes.name: durationMs

attributes.definition:
The ID of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountId is the consumingAccountId. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountId

attributes.definition:
Name of the parent account (also known as the master account) that's either responsible for stored events, or that is the parent of the consuming account.

When a parent account is the consuming account, masterAccountName is the same as consumingAccountName. This attribute is present even for accounts that don't have a parent account. This is to ensure continued reporting if the account is later made a parent account.
attributes.name: masterAccountName

attributes.definition: Consolidates multiple categories of usage into a single metric. Helpful when faceting by productLine.
attributes.name: metric

attributes.definition: When the event was processed by the usage pipeline.
attributes.name: processedTime

attributes.definition: The New Relic product the usage data is from. Use this attribute to identify / filter for product specific usage data.
attributes.name: productLine

attributes.definition:
ID of the child account (also known as the sub-account) responsible for the stored event. When present, subAccountId is the same as consumingAccountId.

This attribute is only present if the consuming account is a child account (not a parent account).
attributes.name: subAccountId

attributes.definition:
Name of the child account (also known as the sub-account) responsible for stored events. When present, this is the same as consumingAccountName.

This attribute is only present if the consuming account is a child account (not a parent account).
attributes.name: subAccountName

attributes.definition: UNIX timestamp (seconds since epoch) of the day and time when event generation was initiated.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: Used with “aggregationFunction” to determine whether aggregation is based on count (sum all usage per hour) or gauge (take max usage per hour).
attributes.name: type

attributes.definition: The amount of usage. The unit varies, depending on the metric field.
attributes.name: usage

name: PageAction
definition: The Browser PageAction event is the result of the addPageAction API call that sends a user-defined name and optional attributes, along with several default attributes, such as app and geographic data. It is used to capture any event that is not already tracked automatically by the Browser agent, such as clicking a Subscribe button or accessing a tutorial.

attributes.definition: The name of the PageAction, as defined by you in your code.
attributes.name: actionName

attributes.definition: The ID of your application, as recorded by New Relic.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the application that handled the request as shown in browser monitoring.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asnLongitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asnOrganization

attributes.definition: The height of the end user's browser window at the time when the PageAction occurred.
attributes.name: browserHeight

attributes.definition: The width of the end user's browser window at the time when the PageAction occurred.
attributes.name: browserWidth

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: countryCode

attributes.definition: The URL on which the PageAction is occurring. This URL may be different from the Page URL.
attributes.name: currentUrl

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: either mobile, tablet, or desktop.
attributes.name: deviceType

attributes.definition: The name of the invoked web transaction. For example: Controller/customers/show.
attributes.name: name

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that was loaded for the PageView, for example: http://www.newrelic.com. This URL does not include query parameters.
attributes.name: pageUrl

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that loaded before the PageAction occurred.
attributes.name: referrerUrl

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the PageView event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes.

In the United States, regions correspond to state codes ; for example, WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes .
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single session. The session cookie expires when the user closes the browser (for example, they fully exit Chrome.) A new session identifier will be assigned when the user opens up a new instance of the browser.
attributes.name: session

attributes.definition: Allows for linking together end user actions from session traces and querying across browser events. Not all browser events will have this. For example, PageView events complete before the first session trace harvest. Also, initial page loads from BrowserInteraction won't always include this.
attributes.name: sessionTraceId

attributes.definition: The time (in seconds) elapsed from when the page was requested to when the PageAction was created.
attributes.name: timeSinceLoad

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The browser’s name, such as Chrome and Firefox, obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentName

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported operating system, such as Windows or Linux, that it is running on. This is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentOS

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported software version, which is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentVersion

name: PageView
definition: PageView events occur when a user navigates to (loads) a new page. It tracks geographic and timing data for each browser page load.

attributes.definition: The ID of your application, as recorded by New Relic.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the application that handled the request as shown in browser monitoring.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asnLongitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asnOrganization

attributes.definition:
The backend response time in seconds.

Includes app server (webAppDuration) and network time (networkDuration), as well as queue time if available. Representative of Time to First Byte. Derived from the Navigation Timing API as responseStart minus navigationStart.
attributes.name: backendDuration

attributes.definition: The transaction name (page view group) as it appears in New Relic Browser.
attributes.name: browserTransactionName

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The time to establish a connection with the server in seconds (inclusive of secureHandshakeDuration). Derived from the Navigation Timing API as connectEnd minus connectStart.
attributes.name: connectionSetupDuration

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: countryCode

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: mobile, tablet, or desktop.
attributes.name: deviceType

attributes.definition: The time to resolve the DNS record for the top-level resource (in seconds). Derived from the Navigation Timing API as domainLookupEnd minus domainLookupStart.
attributes.name: dnsLookupDuration

attributes.definition:
The time it takes to parse the HTML into a DOM and retrieve or execute synchronous scripts.

Often includes time for scripts and static assets to be retrieved. Derived from the Navigation Timing API as domContentLoadedEventEnd minus responseStart.
attributes.name: domProcessingDuration

attributes.definition: The domain portion of the request URL.
attributes.name: domain

attributes.definition: The browser response time in seconds. Derived from the Navigation Timing API as loadEventEnd minus navigationStart.
attributes.name: duration

attributes.definition:
firstContentfulPaint is the point when the browser renders the first bit of content from the DOM, which may be text, an image, SVG, or a <canvas> element.

Google's User-centric Performance Metrics contains detailed information about its Paint Timing API and firstContentfulPaint.

See Compatibility and requirements for New Relic Browser for additional information about firstContentfulPaint browser compatibility.
attributes.name: firstContentfulPaint

attributes.definition:
firstPaint marks the point when the browser renders anything that is visually different from what was on the screen prior to navigation. This includes non-default background paint and the enclosing box of an iframe.

Google's User-centric Performance Metrics contains detailed information about its Paint Timing API and firstPaint.

See Compatibility and requirements for New Relic Browser for additional information about firstPaint browser compatibility.
attributes.name: firstPaint

attributes.definition: The name of the invoked web transaction. For example: Controller/customers/show.
attributes.name: name

attributes.definition: The total time spent in redirects as well as in requesting and receiving HTML (in seconds). If webAppDuration (server side timing information) is not available, time on the server will be included in this duration.
attributes.name: networkDuration

attributes.definition: The page rendering phase is the time between DOM completion (domContentLoadedEventEnd) and the window load event (loadEventEnd), in seconds. This phase measures browser-side processing and display of the page content.
attributes.name: pageRenderingDuration

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that was loaded for the PageView, for example: http://www.newrelic.com. This URL does not include query parameters.
attributes.name: pageUrl

attributes.definition: The total time the request waits for a service to initiate (in seconds).
attributes.name: queueDuration

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the PageView event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes.

In the United States, regions correspond to state codes ; for example, WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes .
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: A subset of connectionSetupDuration, the time to establish a TLS connection with the server. Derived from the Navigation Timing API as connectEnd minus secureConnectionStart (in seconds).
attributes.name: secureHandshakeDuration

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single session. The session cookie expires when the user closes the browser (for example, they fully exit Chrome.) A new session identifier will be assigned when the user opens up a new instance of the browser.
attributes.name: session

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The browser’s name, such as Chrome and Firefox, obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentName

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported operating system, such as Windows or Linux, that it is running on. This is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentOS

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported software version, which is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentVersion

attributes.definition:
The total server-side response time for the top-level resource of the PageView (in seconds) as measured by the APM agent.

This does not include network time to transmit the request or receive the response, or server-side request queueing time. The webAppDuration is measured by the APM agent and must be injected into the browser monitoring script before the request is fully finished. Its end point is slightly before the end point used to calculate the duration attribute on Transactions, so webAppDuration will be slightly less than the duration attribute on Transactions in practice.
attributes.name: webAppDuration

name: PageViewTiming
definition: This event represents individual timing events during a page view lifecycle (for example, time when the largest element is displayed, or the first user interaction with the page). See the PageViewTiming docs for a list of reported events.

attributes.definition: The ID of your application, as recorded by New Relic.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The name of the application that handled the request as shown in browser monitoring.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asnLatitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asnLongitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asnOrganization

attributes.definition: The transaction name (page view group) as it appears in New Relic Browser.
attributes.name: browserTransactionName

attributes.definition: The city in which the event occurred, such as Portland or Seattle.
attributes.name: city

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: countryCode

attributes.definition:
An important, user-centric metric for measuring visual stability because it helps quantify how often users experience unexpected layout shifts—a low CLS helps ensure that the page is delightful.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: cumulativeLayoutShift

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: either mobile, tablet, or desktop.
attributes.name: deviceType

attributes.definition: The domain portion of the request URL.
attributes.name: domain

attributes.definition: This is the ID, if specified, of the largestContentfulPaint element. This value will only be reported with the LCP metric. This value can be null or empty and is captured from the LargestContentfulPaint.id property.
attributes.name: elementId

attributes.definition: This is the reported size of the largestContentfulPaint element. This value will only be reported with the LCP metric and is captured from the LargestContentfulPaint.size property.
attributes.name: elementSize

attributes.definition: This is the tag name of the largestContentfulPaint element. This value will only be reported with the LCP metric and is captured from the LargestContentfulPaint.element.tagName property.
attributes.name: elementTagName

attributes.definition: This is the request url of the largestContentfulPaint element, if the element is an image. This value will only be reported with the LCP metric. The value is captured from the LargestContentfulPaint.url property (if present).
attributes.name: elementUrl

attributes.definition:
The first contentful paint timing rounded down to the nearest second. This attribute only occurs when the value of the timingName attribute is firstContentfulPaint.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: firstContentfulPaint

attributes.definition:
The first input delay measures the duration from the first interaction to the moment the web application responds. The duration is rounded down to the nearest millisecond. This attribute only occurs when the value of the timingName attribute is firstInteraction.

The firstInputDelay goes one step beyond firstInteraction. It measures how long the user has to wait until their action is registered and they receive the expected response from the browser.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: firstInputDelay

attributes.definition:
First interaction is a timing that captures when customers begin to engage with a website, such as clicking a button or typing in a box. The first interaction timing is rounded down to the nearest second. This attribute only occurs when the value of the timingName attribute is firstInteraction.

Events are handled at the document level with addEventListener(). Clicking an empty page will cause an interaction to fire. Valid event type values include:

  • pointerdown
  • mousedown
  • click
  • keydown
  • touchstart

Note that this attribute represents the time of the event; to know which event triggered it, use interactionType.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: firstInteraction

attributes.definition:
The first paint timing rounded down to the nearest second. Occurs when the timingName value is firstPaint.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: firstPaint

attributes.definition:
An experimental metric that assesses responsiveness. A low INP means the page was consistently able to respond quickly to all or nearly all user interactions.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: interactionToNextPaint

attributes.definition:
The event type of the first interaction that occurs on the web application. The type can be one of the following:

  • pointerdown
  • mousedown
  • click
  • keydown
  • touchstart

This attribute only occurs when the value of the timingName attribute is firstInteraction. For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: interactionType

attributes.definition:
This metric reports the render time of the largest content element visible in the viewport, which is a more accurate way to measure when the main content of a page is loaded and useful.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: largestContentfulPaint

attributes.definition:
Generated for every long task entry that the PerformanceLongTaskTiming API observes throughout the life of the page.

For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: longTask

attributes.definition:
This is the estimated effective bandwidth in megabits per second at the time the PageViewTiming event was captured. This value will only be reported with the largestContentfulPaint and firstInteraction events on compatible browsers.

The value is captured from the NetworkInformation API. For a full browser compatibility table and description see the MDN web docs.
attributes.name: networkDownlink

attributes.definition:
This is the effective connection type ('slow-2g', '2g', '3g' or '4g'), of the current network connection at the time the PageViewTiming event was captured. This value will only be reported with the largestContentfulPaint and firstInteraction events on compatible browsers.

The value is captured from the NetworkInformation API. For a full browser compatibility table and description see MDN Web Docs: NetworkInformation.effectiveType. See also Effective connection type for a description of each type.
attributes.name: networkEffectiveType

attributes.definition:
This is the estimated round trip time, in milliseconds, of the current network connection at the time the PageViewTiming event was captured. This value will only be reported with the largestContentfulPaint and firstInteraction events on compatible browsers.

The value is captured from the NetworkInformation API. For a full browser compatibility table and description see the MDN web docs.
attributes.name: networkRtt

attributes.definition:
This is the type of the current network connection at the time the PageViewTiming event was captured. This value will only be reported with the largestContentfulPaint and firstInteraction events on compatible browsers.

The value is captured from the NetworkInformation API. For a full browser compatibility table and description see the MDN web docs.
attributes.name: networkType

attributes.definition: Sent when the document becomes hidden to the user, which could mean the user switched tabs or navigated to another page. This is the most reliable event to indicate the (potential) end of a user session or visit to the page.
attributes.name: pageHide

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that was loaded for the PageView, for example: http://www.newrelic.com. This URL does not include query parameters.
attributes.name: pageUrl

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the PageView event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes.

In the United States, regions correspond to state codes ; for example, WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes .
attributes.name: regionCode

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single session. The session cookie expires when the user closes the browser (for example, they fully exit Chrome.) A new session identifier will be assigned when the user opens up a new instance of the browser.
attributes.name: session

attributes.definition: Allows for linking together end user actions from session traces and querying across browser events. Not all browser events will have this. For example, PageView events complete before the first session trace harvest. Also, initial page loads from BrowserInteraction won't always include this.
attributes.name: sessionTraceId

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition:
The name of the timing event: firstPaint, firstContentfulPaint, or firstInteraction.

The name of the timing event: firstPaint, firstContentfulPaint, or firstInteraction. For more information, see the PageViewTiming documentation.
attributes.name: timingName

attributes.definition: The browser’s name, such as Chrome and Firefox, obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentName

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported operating system, such as Windows or Linux, that it is running on. This is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentOS

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported software version, which is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgentVersion

attributes.definition:
The windowLoad event is fired when the whole has loaded.

See supporting documentation and browser compatibility for the Window Load event MDN docs.
attributes.name: windowLoad

attributes.definition: Sent when the page unloading is detected, which marks the definitive end of a user session or visit to the page.
attributes.name: windowUnload

name: ProcessSample
definition: ProcessSample event gathers detailed resource usage information from programs running on a single system. New Relic samples the data every 20 seconds for every active process and packages it into a ProcessSample event, which then sends the raw data to New Relic's collectors every 60 seconds.

attributes.definition: The name of the agent (Infrastructure).
attributes.name: agentName

attributes.definition: The version of the New Relic Infrastructure agent.
attributes.name: agentVersion

attributes.definition: The full command line for the current process. This command line will be sanitized by default to strip options and arguments from the command line to prevent accidental leakage of private information.
attributes.name: commandLine

attributes.definition:
The command name of the process corresponds, in most cases, to the base name of the command line's path to the form of the process.

In Linux, this attribute is retrieved from `/proc/PID/stat`, in which strings longer than 16 characters are silently truncated. Internally, linux command names can be up to 16 bytes long. More information can be found in the [proc manual pages](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/proc.5.html).
attributes.name: commandName

attributes.definition: Returns true if the process is running inside a container; false if not inside a container.
attributes.name: contained

attributes.definition: For processes running inside a Docker container, the unique Docker container ID for this process.
attributes.name: containerId

attributes.definition: For processes running inside a Docker container, the Docker image ID for the image this process is based on.
attributes.name: containerImage

attributes.definition: For processes running inside a Docker container, the Docker image name for this process.
attributes.name: containerImageName

attributes.definition:
For processes running inside a Docker container, the Docker label associated with this process.

Docker labels consist of key/value pairs. The key is captured in the attribute name as containerLabel_KEY, and the returned stringtype value is then associated with that attribute.

For example, to query a owner label for containers maintained by Test User:

SELECT cpuPercent FROM ProcessSample WHERE containerLabel_owner = 'Test User'
attributes.name: containerLabel_KEY

attributes.definition: For processes running inside a Docker container, the Docker container name for this process
attributes.name: containerName

attributes.definition: The combined CPU usage (of all types, including system, user, I/O, depending on platform), by CPU core, for this process at a single point in time. For systems with more than one CPU core, this percentage may be greater than 100%.
attributes.name: cpuPercent

attributes.definition: The system-time CPU usage component used by the process.
attributes.name: cpuSystemPercent

attributes.definition: The user-time CPU usage component used by the process.
attributes.name: cpuUserPercent

attributes.definition: The number of times that alert conditions violated critical thresholds, causing critical violations and opening incidents. If this attribute does not exist on the sample, it has zero violations.
attributes.name: criticalViolationCount

attributes.definition: New Relic's unique ID number for the entity that is reporting data. This is used by New Relic to distinguish between customers and their entities.
attributes.name: entityID

attributes.definition: The fully qualified (DNS) hostname.
attributes.name: fullHostname

attributes.definition: The short version of the entity's name.
attributes.name: hostname

attributes.definition: The number of bytes read from all storage devices per second.
attributes.name: ioReadBytesPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of disk read operations by the process per second.
attributes.name: ioReadCountPerSecond

attributes.definition:
Counts bytes that the process caused to be fetched from the storage layer.

Count of bytes that the process caused to be fetched from the storage layer. Done at submit_bio() level, so it's accurate for block-backed filesystems. Read from the /proc/PID/io file, where PID is the ID of the process being monitored.
attributes.name: ioTotalReadBytes

attributes.definition: Cumulative number of disk read operations by this process.
attributes.name: ioTotalReadCount

attributes.definition:
Counts bytes that the process caused to be sent to the storage layer.

Counts bytes that the process caused to be sent to the storage layer. This is done at page-dirtying time. Read from the /proc/PID/io file, where PID is the ID of the process being monitored.
attributes.name: ioTotalWriteBytes

attributes.definition: Cumulative number of disk write operations by this process.
attributes.name: ioTotalWriteCount

attributes.definition: The number of bytes written by this process per second.
attributes.name: ioWriteBytesPerSecond

attributes.definition: The number of disk write operations by the process per second.
attributes.name: ioWriteCountPerSecond

attributes.definition:
The Linux kernel version, in string format.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Linux platform.
attributes.name: kernelVersion

attributes.definition:
The name of the Linux distribution the server is using.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Linux platform.
attributes.name: linuxDistribution

attributes.definition: The total amount of physical memory in use for the process, in bytes.
attributes.name: memoryResidentSizeBytes

attributes.definition: The total amount of virtual memory reserved for the process, in bytes.
attributes.name: memoryVirtualSizeBytes

attributes.definition: The operating system on which the agent is installed.
attributes.name: operatingSystem

attributes.definition: The unique parent identification number (PID) for this process.
attributes.name: parentProcessId

attributes.definition:
The display name (friendly name) of the process.

This is derived from the command name by default, but if it can be determined that the process is associated with a service from the inventory system, New Relic uses the service name. Another source of the name may be a parsed component of the command line, if it is a known command line format (for example, Java app).
attributes.name: processDisplayName

attributes.definition: The unique process identification number for this process.
attributes.name: processId

attributes.definition: The current process status as a platform-specific state name. For example: running or sleeping.
attributes.name: state

attributes.definition: The number of threads active for this process.
attributes.name: threadCount

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The user identifier under which the process is running.
attributes.name: userId

attributes.definition: The username of the owner of the process; for example, root or ubuntu.
attributes.name: userName

attributes.definition: The number of times that alert conditions violated warning thresholds, causing warning violations.
attributes.name: warningViolationCount

attributes.definition:
The Windows family indicates whether the OS is a server or desktop targeted system.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Windows platform.
attributes.name: windowsFamily

attributes.definition:
The full product name of the installed version of Windows.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Windows platform.
attributes.name: windowsPlatform

attributes.definition:
The combined Windows version and build-number string of the OS.

This attribute is available only for systems on a Windows platform.
attributes.name: windowsVersion

name: ServiceLevelSnapshot
definition: This event is created when we periodically calculate the compliance and remaining error budget for a given service level entity.

attributes.definition: The service level entity name.
attributes.name: entity.name

attributes.definition: The remaining error budget (based on the SLI compliance and the service level objective).
attributes.name: remainingErrorBudget

attributes.definition: The service level compliance (% of good vs valid events) calculated for the configured SLO time window (1d, 7d or 28d).
attributes.name: sliCompliance

attributes.definition: The time at which the calculation was done, in Unix time.
attributes.name: timestamp

name: Span
definition: Span events are created when New Relic agents, or other tracing instrumentation tools, instrument operations that are part of a distributed trace. The operations that a span can represent include datastore queries, calls to other services, and method-level timing. For example, in an HTTP service, a span is created at the beginning of an HTTP request and completed when the HTTP server returns a response. Span attributes contain important information about the operation that the span represents (such as duration, host data, etc.), including trace state details (such as traceId, guid) that allow New Relic to connect spans together in a trace.

attributes.definition: The unique numeric identifier assigned by New Relic for the service/app that generated the transaction.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The application name set in the New Relic agent configuration.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: Autonomous System Number: a unique number identifying a group of IP networks that serves the content to the end user.
attributes.name: asn

attributes.definition: The latitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's latitude.
attributes.name: asn.latitude

attributes.definition: The longitude of the geographic center of the postal code where the Autonomous System Network is registered. This is not the end user's longitude.
attributes.name: asn.longitude

attributes.definition: The organization that owns the Autonomous System Number. Often an ISP, sometimes a private company or institution.
attributes.name: asn.organization

attributes.definition: The name of the browser application monitored by New Relic.
attributes.name: browserApp.name

attributes.definition: A unique value generated for each browser interaction captured by the New Relic agent.
attributes.name: browserInteraction.id

attributes.definition: The name of the interaction. This is either the targetGroupedUrl or the custom name set via the API.
attributes.name: browserInteraction.name

attributes.definition: Optional: If the application received a response from the request.url, this is the size of that response in bytes.
attributes.name: bytes.received

attributes.definition: Optional: If the application sent a request to the request.url, this is the size of that request in bytes.
attributes.name: bytes.sent

attributes.definition: The type of span. Values include: generic, datastore, and http (external). The category type dictates UI display options (available charts, for example) and the collection of specific attributes.
attributes.name: category

attributes.definition: The absolute path to the source code file where the span's instrumented function is defined. Supports the New Relic CodeStream code-level metrics integration.
attributes.name: code.filepath

attributes.definition: The name of the instrumented function or method associated with the span. Supports the New Relic CodeStream code-level metrics integration.
attributes.name: code.function

attributes.definition: The line number where the span's instrumented function is defined. Supports the New Relic CodeStream code-level metrics integration.
attributes.name: code.lineno

attributes.definition: The namespace (class/ module name) in which the span's instrumented function is defined. Supports the New Relic CodeStream code-level metrics integration.
attributes.name: code.namespace

attributes.definition: For 'datastore' category spans: the database vendor or driver, such as Redis and MySql. For 'external' category spans: the framework used to make the connection. For example: OkHttp and Net::HTTP.
attributes.name: component

attributes.definition: The type of connection which the device was using, such as 2G or 3G.
attributes.name: connection.type

attributes.definition: The container ID. The New Relic APM agent collects this when running in a containerized context.
attributes.name: containerId

attributes.definition: The database name. For example, the name of the database for a given JDBC database connection URL in Java. Reported when the category is 'datastore.' Example value: dbc.url="jdbc:mysql://mysql-db.servers.net:3306/accounts".
attributes.name: db.instance

attributes.definition: The database statement in the format most permissive by configuration. Reported when 'category' is 'datastore.' For a span with a 'component' of 'MySql', an example value would be: SELECT * FROM accounts.
attributes.name: db.statement

attributes.definition: The display size of the device: small, normal, large, xlarge.
attributes.name: device.size

attributes.definition: The type of device that loaded the page: mobile, tablet, or desktop.
attributes.name: device.type

attributes.definition: The span's elapsed time in seconds.
attributes.name: duration

attributes.definition: The span's elapsed time in milliseconds.
attributes.name: duration.ms

attributes.definition: The GUID, assigned by New Relic, for the New Relic-monitored entity (host, application, etc.). This value is stored as a Base64 encoded value.
attributes.name: entity.guid

attributes.definition: The name of the entity (for example, an app name, host name, or workload name).
attributes.name: entity.name

attributes.definition: Makes a span as having an error.
attributes.name: error

attributes.definition: The full class name for the span's error.
attributes.name: error.class

attributes.definition: The message for the span's error.
attributes.name: error.message

attributes.definition: HTTP error response code. Only present when code represents either a client error or server error.
attributes.name: error.statusCode

attributes.definition: Either HTTPError or NetworkFailure, depending on whether the error is a result of a failed request to a host or a failure on the cellular network.
attributes.name: error.type

attributes.definition: The city in which the span occurred.
attributes.name: geo.city

attributes.definition: The country from which the browser initiated the page load. For a list of country codes, see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
attributes.name: geo.countryCode

attributes.definition:
The specific administrative division within a country where the event occurred. In the United States, regions correspond to state codes, such as WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numeric codes.

In the United States, regions correspond to state codes ; for example, WA or NY. Outside the United States, a country's regions correspond to numerical codes .
attributes.name: geo.regionCode

attributes.definition: The grouped URL of the view that made the AJAX request. For example: myapp.com/acct/*/dash.
attributes.name: groupedPageUrl

attributes.definition: The grouped URL of the AJAX request. For example: myapp.com/acct/\*/ajax.
attributes.name: groupedRequestUrl

attributes.definition: The unique identifier for the segment. This is equivalent to spanID in OpenTracing semantics.
attributes.name: guid

attributes.definition: The name of the application host that processed this request, as identified by the reporting agent. Examples: ip-10-1-34-88, ede2fff1efbe, apphost.domain.com.
attributes.name: host

attributes.definition: The HTTP method or language method/function used for the call. Reported when the category is http. Examples: GET, POST.
attributes.name: http.method

attributes.definition: The HTTP status code associated with the transaction. Some agents use httpResponseCode, which is equivalent.
attributes.name: http.statusCode

attributes.definition: The response status message for a web request.
attributes.name: http.statusText

attributes.definition: External URI for the call. Reported when 'category' is 'http.' It MUST NOT contain user, password, or query parameters. It MUST be set as an agent attribute and not as an intrinsic so that attribute filtering can be applied.
attributes.name: http.url

attributes.definition: The HTTP response code associated with the transaction. Some agents use http.statusCode, which is equivalent.
attributes.name: httpResponseCode

attributes.definition: The total duration, in milliseconds, spent on JavaScript execution. (This attribute doesn't exist for initial page load events.)
attributes.name: jsDuration.ms

attributes.definition: The name of the mobile application that created this span.
attributes.name: mobileApp.name

attributes.definition: The span name that best represents the operation.
attributes.name: name

attributes.definition: The error message associated with the iOS NSURL Error code. See networkError.code for more information.
attributes.name: networkError

attributes.definition: If the error is a network error, this is the iOS network error code. For Android applications, this is the mapped value.
attributes.name: networkError.code

attributes.definition: Where the data point entered the platform (such as browser.spans, or api.traces).
attributes.name: newRelic.ingestPoint

attributes.definition: The name of the trace filter used by the Infinite Tracing trace observer to select this trace.
attributes.name: newRelic.traceFilter.type

attributes.definition: The URL of the page that was loaded for the PageView, for example: http://www.newrelic.com. This URL does not include query parameters.
attributes.name: pageUrl

attributes.definition: The span parent's GUID (may not be present for the root span).
attributes.name: parentId

attributes.definition: The address of the datastore, including the host name and the port, path, or ID. Reported when 'category' is 'datastore.' Example: mysql-db.servers.net:3306.
attributes.name: peer.address

attributes.definition: The hostname of the database. Reported when 'category' is 'datastore.' Example: mysql-db.servers.net.
attributes.name: peer.hostname

attributes.definition: The request port.
attributes.name: port

attributes.definition: A priority ranking that dictates whether the trace will be reported in situations where the sampling reservoir has exceeded capacity. This is a float value set by the first New Relic agent that’s part of the request.
attributes.name: priority

attributes.definition: The ID of the New Relic agent that reported the data.
attributes.name: realAgentId

attributes.definition: The payload size of the request body, in bytes.
attributes.name: request.bodySize

attributes.definition: The fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the request URL.
attributes.name: request.domain

attributes.definition: The HTTP request method used. Example values: POST, GET.
attributes.name: request.method

attributes.definition: The path that the application attempted to access when the request or error occurred.
attributes.name: request.path

attributes.definition: The URL of the AJAX request. For example: myapp.com/acct/1/ajax.
attributes.name: request.url

attributes.definition: Optional: The response that is sent from the requestDomain for the HTTP error (up to 4096 bytes).
attributes.name: response.body

attributes.definition: The payload size of the response body, in bytes.
attributes.name: response.bodySize

attributes.definition: The HTTP response code. Example: 200.
attributes.name: response.statusCode

attributes.definition: Whether the request route was chosen to be sampled for tracing.
attributes.name: sampled

attributes.definition: The name of the instrumented service that created this span.
attributes.name: service.name

attributes.definition: A unique identifier for a single session. The session cookie expires when the user closes the browser (for example, they fully exit Chrome.) A new session identifier will be assigned when the user opens up a new instance of the browser.
attributes.name: session

attributes.definition: Spans that represent a call to another service or to a datastore have the value client.
attributes.name: span.kind

attributes.definition: The time in milliseconds between the start of the BrowserInteraction and the start of the request.
attributes.name: timeSinceBrowserInteractionStart.ms

attributes.definition: The duration, in milliseconds, from the start of the request (timestamp) to the end of the last callback. This is not just an additive function; the callback time can overlap with the wait time.
attributes.name: timeToLastCallbackEnd.ms

attributes.definition: The time, in milliseconds, from the start of the interaction to the loadEventStart, as defined by the Navigation Timing API. This attribute exists for initial page load events, not route changes.
attributes.name: timeToLoadEventStart.ms

attributes.definition: The time, in milliseconds, from the start of the request to when all resulting callbacks (including callbacks of subsequent AJAX requests) are complete.
attributes.name: timeToSettle.ms

attributes.definition: The time (date, hour, minute, second) at which the interaction occurred.
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The unique ID (a randomly generated string) used to identify a single request as it crosses inter- and intra- process boundaries. This ID allows the linking of spans in a distributed trace. Included when distributed tracing is enabled.
attributes.name: trace.id

attributes.definition: The unique ID (a randomly generated string) used to identify a single request as it crosses inter- and intra- process boundaries. This ID allows the linking of spans in a distributed trace. Included when distributed tracing is enabled.
attributes.name: traceId

attributes.definition: The name of the New Relic transaction associated with the span.
attributes.name: transaction.name

attributes.definition: The GUID of the New Relic transaction associated with the span.
attributes.name: transactionId

attributes.definition: The browser’s name, such as Chrome and Firefox, obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgent.name

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported operating system, such as Windows or Linux, that it is running on. This is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgent.os

attributes.definition: The browser’s reported software version, which is obtained from the User-Agent header of an HTTP request.
attributes.name: userAgent.version

name: StorageSample
definition: StorageSample event represents a single storage device associated with a server. Each sample gathers descriptive information about the device, the type of file system it uses, and its current usage and capacity. New Relic samples this data every 20 seconds for each mounted file system and packages it into a StorageSample event, then sends the raw data to New Relic's collectors every 60 seconds.

attributes.definition: The name of the agent (Infrastructure).
attributes.name: agentName

attributes.definition: The version of the New Relic Infrastructure agent.
attributes.name: agentVersion

attributes.definition:
The average disk queue length derived from (Disk Transfers/sec) * (Disk secs/Transfer).

This metric is only available for the Windows Infrastructure agent, version 1.5.0 or higher.

This value coincides with the following Windows Performance counter:

\LogicalDisk(<drive letter>)\Avg. Disk Queue Length
attributes.name: avgQueueLen

attributes.definition:
The average disk read queue length derived from (Disk Reads/sec) * (Disk secs/Read).

This metric is only available for the Windows Infrastructure agent, version 1.5.0 or higher.

This value coincides with the following Windows Performance counter:

\LogicalDisk(<drive letter>)\Avg. Disk Read Queue Length
attributes.name: avgReadQueueLen

attributes.definition:
The average disk write queue length derived from (Disk Writes/sec) * (Disk secs/Write)

This metric is only available for the Windows Infrastructure agent, version 1.5.0 or higher.

This value coincides with the following Windows Performance counter:

\LogicalDisk(<drive letter>)\Avg. Disk Write Queue Length
attributes.name: avgWriteQueueLen

attributes.definition: The number of times that alert conditions violated critical thresholds, causing critical violations and opening incidents. If this attribute does not exist on the sample, it has zero violations.
attributes.name: criticalViolationCount

attributes.definition:
Length of the disk queue at the time of sampling.

This metric is only available for the Windows Infrastructure Agent, version 1.5.0 or higher.

This value coincides with the following Windows Performance counter:

\LogicalDisk(<drive letter>)\Current Disk Queue Length
attributes.name: currentQueueLen

attributes.definition: The device name.
attributes.name: device

attributes.definition: The cumulative disk space that is free across all supported devices. (To find per-device values, use StorageSample events.)
attributes.name: diskFreeBytes

attributes.definition: The cumulative disk emptiness percentage across all supported devices. To find per-device values, use StorageSample events.
attributes.name: diskFreePercent

attributes.definition: The cumulative total disk space across all supported devices. To find per-device values, use StorageSample events.
attributes.name: diskTotalBytes

attributes.definition: The cumulative disk space used across all supported devices, in bytes. To find per-device values, use StorageSample events.
attributes.name: diskUsedBytes

name: SyntheticCheck
definition: SyntheticCheck returns metrics from one run of a specific monitor. These metrics include duration information for the monitor, location of the monitor check, size of the request and response headers, the type of monitor, and a timestamp. Each time a synthetic monitor runs a check, details about the check are captured in the SyntheticCheck event type. SyntheticCheck events contain details specific to the check to provide visibility such as the status, type of monitor, and size of request and response headers.

name: SyntheticRequest
definition: SyntheticRequest returns results from individual HTTP requests made during a check. With each simple or scripted monitor check, we capture each individual HTTP request made during the check. The HTTP details are captured at a more granular level than the SyntheticsCheck event type.

name: SystemSample
definition: The SystemSample event aggregates data describing the current overall state of the entire server. This data appears in the New Relic Infrastructure Hosts page to show usage trends for the associated host's main resources. These resources include CPU, memory, disk, and network. New Relic samples this data every 5 seconds and packages it into a SystemSample event, then sends the raw data to New Relic's collectors every 60 seconds.

attributes.definition: The portion of free memory available to the server.
attributes.name: MemoryFreePercent

attributes.definition: The name of the agent (Infrastructure).
attributes.name: agentName

attributes.definition: The version of the New Relic Infrastructure agent.
attributes.name: agentVersion

attributes.definition:
• Linux: [/proc/cpuinfo: 'cpu cores'] The number of cores within a single CPU.

  • Windows: [WMI win32_processor: 'NumberOfLogicalProcessors'] The number of logical processors, including cores divided by hyperthreading.
attributes.name: coreCount

attributes.definition:
The portion of the current CPU utilization capacity that is idle.

This is calculated as:

(100.00 - cpuUserPercent - cpuSystemPercent - cpuIOWaitPercent) / elapsed_time
attributes.name: cpuIdlePercent

attributes.definition:
The portion of the current CPU utilization composed only of I/O wait time usage.

This is calculated as:

current_sample_io_time - previous_sample_io_time) / elapsed_time
attributes.name: cpuIoWaitPercent

attributes.definition:
Total CPU utilization as a percentage. This is not an actual recorded value; it is an alias that combines percentage data from cpuSystemPercent, cpuUserPercent, cpuIoWaitPercent and cpuStealPercent.

This is calculated as:

(cpuUserPercent + cpuSystemPercent + cpuIOWaitPercent + cpuStealPercent)
attributes.name: cpuPercent

attributes.definition: The portion of time when a virtualized CPU is waiting for the hypervisor to make real CPU time available to it.
attributes.name: cpuStealPercent

attributes.definition:
The portion of the current CPU utilization composed only of system time usage.

This is calculated as:

(current_sample_sys_time - previous_sample_sys_time) / elapsed_time
attributes.name: cpuSystemPercent

attributes.definition:
The portion of the current CPU utilization composed only of user time usage.

This is calculated as:

current_sample_user_time - previous_sample_user_time) / elapsed_time
attributes.name: cpuUserPercent

attributes.definition: The number of times that alert conditions violated critical thresholds, causing critical violations and opening incidents. If this attribute does not exist on the sample, it has zero violations.

name: Transaction
definition: A transaction is a logical unit of work in a software application, such as HTTP requests, SQL queries, background processes, message queue activity, etc. The Transaction event includes information about the app, database calls, the duration of the transaction, and any errors that may occur.

attributes.definition: The unique ID of the account associated with the service/application where the Transaction was created.
attributes.name: accountId

attributes.definition: The unique numeric identifier assigned by New Relic for the service/app that generated the transaction.
attributes.name: appId

attributes.definition: The application name set in the New Relic agent configuration.
attributes.name: appName

attributes.definition: The number of database calls made by this transaction.
attributes.name: databaseCallCount

attributes.definition: The database response time in seconds.
attributes.name: databaseDuration

attributes.definition: The total server-side response time for the transaction, in seconds. Does not include request queueing time.
attributes.name: duration

attributes.definition: Indicates whether an error was noticed during execution.
attributes.name: error

attributes.definition: (.NET and PHP agents only) This will be server and platform specific. The message contained within an error for the transaction. If an error occurs during a transaction, the error may skew the duration of the event.
attributes.name: errorMessage

attributes.definition: This will be server and platform specific. The class or classification of the error. If multiple errors occur, only the first will be shown. If an error occurs during a transaction, the error may skew the duration of the event.
attributes.name: errorType

attributes.definition: The time the transaction spent running the event loop. (Python agent only)
attributes.name: eventLoopTime

attributes.definition: Total time the transaction was running while blocked by an event loop process, subject to the threshold. (Python agent only)
attributes.name: eventLoopWait

attributes.definition: The number of external calls made by this transaction.
attributes.name: externalCallCount

attributes.definition: The total response time of all external (out-of-process) services, in seconds.
attributes.name: externalDuration

attributes.definition: (Ruby and Java agents only) The total time spent in garbage collection during this transaction, in seconds.

attributes.definition: The identifier for the transaction.
attributes.name: guid

attributes.definition: The name of the application host that processed this request.
attributes.name: host

attributes.name: http.statusText

attributes.definition: The name of the transaction associated with this data. Ex: Controller/customers/show.

attributes.name: parent.transportType

attributes.definition: If a distributed trace payload was received, the parent's data source type. Example values: App, Browser, Mobile.
attributes.name: parent.type

attributes.definition: If a distributed trace payload was received, the guid of this parent transaction.
attributes.name: parentId

attributes.definition: Likelihood this event will be saved.

name: Vulnerability
definition: New Relic Vulnerability Management is an opinionated solution that helps Devs, SREs, and Infosec teams build and run secure software with more confidence and less effort by centralizing, organizing, and prioritizing security risks in observability context.

attributes.definition: The common vulnerability and exposure ID assigned by the disclosing agency.
attributes.name: cve

attributes.definition: The vulnerablity's CVSS score as assigned by the disclosing agency.
attributes.name: cvss.score

attributes.definition: A breakdown of the CVSS score's components as assigned by the disclosing agency.
attributes.name: cvss.vector

attributes.definition: Long form description of the vulnerability. May include exploit risks, specific versions, other links.
attributes.name: description

attributes.definition: A URL linking to detailed information on the vulnerability from the disclosing agency.

attributes.definition: The unique ID of the New Relic entity impacted by the vulnerability.

attributes.name: entityType

attributes.definition: The unique ID assigned to the vulnerability by the disclosing agency.
attributes.name: issue.id

attributes.definition: The type of issue, for example library vulnerability or misconfiguration.
attributes.name: issue.type

attributes.definition: The unique ID assigned to this instance of the vulnerablity by the disclosing agency.
attributes.name: issue.vendor.id

attributes.name: issueId

attributes.name: package

attributes.name: rawPayload

attributes.definition: A short description of the vulnerabilty.

name: WorkloadStatus
definition: The workload status is derived from the alerting status of entities in your workload. This allows you to set up an alert condition to notify you whenever the workload goes into a DISRUPTED or DEGRADED status.

attributes.definition: The name of the entity (for example, an app name, host name, or workload name).
attributes.name: entity.name

attributes.definition: Human-readable value of the workload status: OPERATIONAL, DEGRADED, DISRUPTED, or UNKNOWN.
attributes.name: statusValue

attributes.definition: Numerical status code that can be used in alert conditions. 0 (operational), 2 (degraded), 3 (disrupted) or -99 (unknown). For more information, see our workload status docs.
attributes.name: statusValueCode

attributes.definition:
Time that the event occurred or was evaluated over. Specifies a time or range of time. Examples:

  • MM-DD-YYYY HH:MM:SS
  • SINCE 2018-05-28 11:18:45
  • UNTIL 30 minutes ago
  • SINCE '2018-06-20' UNTIL today
attributes.name: timestamp

attributes.definition: The New Relic-assigned GUID for a workload.
attributes.name: workloadGuid
